title: ID in the News� Blog Archive �  Maxine Carr wins identity secrecy
text:
ID in the News� Blog Archive
 �  Maxine Carr wins identity secrecy

	
	






	
		
			ID in the News			

		
			The latest on Identity Cards and Databases in the UK		

	




	
				
  	
		
			� You do not fight terror with an ID card

			 Scotland says NO! to ID �

		

	
		
			Maxine Carr wins identity secrecy

	
			
				The BBC report that Maxine Carr has been granted an indefinite order protecting her new identity by the High Court.

This highlights numerous weaknesses in the case for biometric identity documents of any kind.

Under identity card plans that include supposedly infallible biometrics those who require a new identity will no longer be able to maintain it and leave the country.  Travel abroad will be impossible if the person has been to the same country under the previous identity (presuming the other country retains a biometric record.)  (See SpyBlog?s extensive writing on this).

Whatever you feel about the specific case of Maxine Carr, there are numerous people who will require a change of identity in their lives ? witnesses to serious crimes, undercover agents, people fleeing persecution ? the list is probably longer than you initially think.

Another issue raised is that for a new indentity to be maintained within the UK there must be an official mechanism to erase past identities.  Where there is an official mechanism there is a greater liklihood that unnofficial erasures will also take place.  The greatest threats that identity cards are supposedly going to protect us from will be the same ones that take advantage of these mechanisms.  This being the case we are left with an identity register we can?t really trust, as well as people running it we can?t trust.

	
					
				
					
						This entry was posted
						 
						by WP Admin on Thursday, February 24th, 2005 at 16:47						and is filed under Neutral,  UK News Articles.
						You can follow any responses to this entry through the RSS 2.0 feed. 
						
													Both comments and pings are currently closed.

Dr Hamber says: “This is a particularly exciting time for Healing Through 
Remembering. The issue of dealing with the past, which has been the key 
focus of the organisation for the last seven years, is squarely on the agenda. 
http://www.healingthroughremembering.org/b_news/pressrelease.asp?pressID=20 (1 of 2)12/10/2007 14:04:56Healing Through Remembering
The key question now is: how is that past actually going to be dealt with? 
"The role of Healing Through Remembering will be to stimulate debate, but 
 also to begin to offer concrete directions on the way forward. This is a 
difficult task, but the organisation has grown and is in a good position to 
  
 
tackle these difficult issues. “The membership is genuinely cross-community 
and the organisation represents a diverse spectrum of opinion. This diversity 
 
is the strength of Healing Through Remembering". "I look forward to working 
with the membership and key stakeholders to capitalise on all that has been 
achieved so far. International experience of conflict from Spain to Chile tells 
us that the past will not disappear… the question is how best can it be dealt 
with in a way that is inclusive and positive for society." 
 
Dr Hamber was a visiting Tip O'Neill Fellow in Peace Studies at INCORE in 
1997/1998. He was also the recipient of the Rockefeller Resident Fellowship 
(1996) and was a visiting fellow at the Centre for the Study of Violence in Sao 
Paulo, Brazil.

	Standing up for Wales

Sefyll Cornel Cymru




	
	  
	    

"At the heart of all we do will be our determination to fight for jobs and grow the Welsh economy. Ours is an ambitious, positive vision of the nation we can become. In everything we do we will stand up for Wales and lead our country forward with ambition."

"Bydd ein penderfyniad diwyro i frwydro dros swyddi ac i dyfu economi Cymru wrth wraidd popeth rydyn ni’n ei wneud. Mae gennym weledigaeth uchelgeisiol a chadarnhaol o’r wlad y gallwn ni fod. Felly byddwn yn sefyll yn gadarn dros Gymru ym mhopeth yr ydym yn ei wneud, ac yn arwain ein gwlad ag uchelgais."


	  

	





  Latest News Newyddion

  
     
    
    
		
		
			Cabinet Announcement

			
			    

			    First Minister Carwyn Jones has announced the members of his new Cabinet as the Welsh Government begins its ambitious programme to stand up for Wales and create a country of equality, opportunity and social justice. 
                
Read more...

			

		

		
		
			Statement by Carwyn Jones

			
			    

			    I have invited you here this morning to bring you up to date on developments following last week’s election and to explain what will happen next, in terms of forming a stable Government to serve the people of Wales.

It is clear that whilst falling just short of an outright majority last week, Welsh Labour clearly won this election: in terms of seats, share of the vote and number of votes cast.  
                
Read more...

			

		

		
		
			Send Tories A Message Over Coastguard Closures, Says Carwyn

			
			    

			    Welsh Labour today stepped up its campaign to save two Welsh Coastguard stations with an advertising campaign in West Wales.

As thousands of people flock to the seaside this bank holiday weekend, Welsh Labour will be using their digital AdVan to warn voters of the threat to coastguard stations in Milford Haven and Holyhead. The consultation period for the coastguard closure plans ends on May 6th – a day after the Assembly elections. 
                
Read more...

			

		

		

        

        Page 1
2
3
4
5
6

 of 6 | next »

    




  

  
      
    
    
		
		
			Mae Carwyn Jones wedi cyhoeddi ei Gabinet newydd 

			
			    

			    Mae Carwyn Jones, Prif Weinidog Cymru, wedi cyhoeddi pwy fydd aelodau ei Gabinet newydd wrth i Lywodraeth Cymru ddechrau ar ei rhaglen uchelgeisiol i sefyll yn gadarn dros Gymru. Y nod yw creu gwlad lle mae cydraddoldeb, cyfleoedd a chyfiawnder cymdeithasol wedi ennill eu plwy. 
                
Darllen hychwaneg...

			

		

		
		
			Datganiad gan Carwyn Jones

			
			    

			    Rwyf wedi’ch gwahodd yma’r bore ‘ma i roi’r datblygiadau diweddaraf i chi yn dilyn yr etholiad yr wythnos diwethaf ac i esbonio beth fydd yn digwydd nesaf, o ran ffurfio Llywodraeth sefydlog i wasanaethu pobl Cymru.

Mae’n amlwg, er i ni fethu o drwch blewyn i gael mwyafrif llwyr yr wythnos diwethaf, bod Llafur Cymru wedi ennill yr etholiad hwn: o ran seddi, cyfran o’r bleidlais a nifer y pleidleisiau a fwriwyd.   
                
Darllen hychwaneg...

			

		

		
		
			Anfonwch Neges I’R Torïaid Ynghylch Cael Gwared Ar Wylwyr Y Glannau, Meddai Carwyn

			
			    

			    Mae Llafur Cymru heddiw wedi dwysáu ei ymgyrch i achub dwy orsaf Gwylwyr y Glannau yng Nghymru gydag ymgyrch hysbysebu yng Ngorllewin Cymru.

Wrth i filoedd o bobl heidio i lan y môr dros benwythnos gŵyl y banc, bydd Llafur Cymru’n defnyddio’u cerbyd hysbysebu digidol i rybuddio pleidleiswyr am y bygythiad i orsafoedd gwylwyr y glannau yn Aberdaugleddau a Chaergybi. Mae’r cyfnod ymgynghori ar gyfer y cynlluniau i gau gorsafoedd gwylwyr y glannau’n dod i ben ar 6 Mai - diwrnod ar ôl etholiadau’r Cynulliad. 
                
Darllen hychwaneg...

 2
Central Area Planning Committee - 
                             4th March 2010
Percentage
Percentage
Percentage3.0  COMMENT 
 
3.1 The performance figures for the third quarter of the year generally build on the excellent 
performance last year.  The development control service has exceeded all three national 
targets by a significant margin. 
 
3.2 The Service continues to achieve top quartile nationally (local target) across two of the 
three categories of planning applications (minors and others), which is highly 
commendable representing a consistently high level of performance.  As with the second 
quarter of the year, the speed with which the ‘major’ applications are being determined has 
fallen below the top quartile standard achieved last year. This is predominantly a result of 
the reduced number of smaller, more straightforward ‘major’ applications received which 
can normally be decided within the 13-week period.  These decisions tend to 
counterbalance those made on the larger scale ‘major’ applications which are unable to be 
decided within 13-weeks because of the complexity of issues.   
 
3.3 Officers are seeking to improve overall performance in three main ways: 
 
a) Increase the capacity of professional planning officers by training the support team 
to carry out some of the tasks currently undertaken by planning officers e.g. appeal 
questionnaires and associated documentation, and 
b) The more junior planning officers are being developed to enable them to take on 
some of the more difficult cases thereby freeing up senior officers to focus on the 
larger scale schemes. 
c) A ‘general enquiries’ phone number has been set up which is operated by Support 
Team officers.  This has had the effect of reducing the number of general calls 
taken by planning officers which allows them to focus on the professional work for 
which they are trained. 
 
3.3 Planning appeal performance is no longer a national performance indicator.  It is however 
a good indicator of the quality of decisions taken by the Council and as such this will 
continue to be monitored and reported to Members.  Overall performance in the third 
quarter of the year was similar to the national average (33%) and is not a cause for 
concern.  The overall figure does however disguise some more specific areas where 
performance is far below the national average.  The fact that 65% of appeals against the 
decisions of South Area Planning Committee and 67% of those of Central Committee were 
allowed does indicate an area that needs to be monitored and addressed.  Officers and 
the Chairmen and Vice-Chairmen of all 4 planning committees considered the issue at 
their recent quarterly meeting. 
 
4.0 RECOMMENDATION 
 
4.1 Members are requested to note this report.

Archived Current Debates







    
    
        
            03
        
            NOV
        
    

    
        Who will atheist buses benefit?
    

	Mike Elms

    

    
        105
    

    Comments 
        | Latest by
        Greywizard
        ,
        10 Nov
    
    

    

        
        
I�??ve never met Richard Dawkins but I would very much like to thank him for throwing his influence and money behind the �??atheist bus�?? ad campaign, which is due to run in January. It should, I hope, play an important part in this country�??s Christian revival.

 

The reason lies in some basic principles of marketing.

 

The biggest threat to a product is very often not competition but the lack of it, with resultant consumer apathy leading to market stagnation or decline.

 

Put simply, when one has a long-established, well-known, well-loved even, but somewhat generic product, i.e. when the product is the market, it can be very difficult to maintain a high degree of positive interest and engagement among its users.

 

But if and when competition arrives (and it usually does), it forces a re-evaluation of attitudes and creates an opportunity for the product to re-connect with a market suddenly forced to a point of choice. Suddenly �??consumers�?? are faced with the need to make a conscious decision about whether and what to buy. In such circumstances, growth in the overall market is not an uncommon occurrence. The resurgence of board games in general, and Monopoly in particular, after the market entry of Trivial Pursuit is such an example.

 

For too long, the British public has been able to dodge the �??God choice�?? �?? is there or isn�??t there? �?? by scribbling C of E on their hospital admission form. But now atheists are challenging us to make that choice one way or another. And they are doing so at a most opportune time.

 

This country has never been more prosperous or more satiated with material possessions, yet research shows that its inhabitants are no happier for it and, in some ways, are significantly unhappier.

 

The �??Big Questions�?? �?? �??Who am I?�??; �??Why am I here?�??; �??Where am I going?�?? �?? become ever more insistent as they are demonstrably not answered by financial security and material possessions (and the credit crunch and global recession now threaten even those).

 

Other research has shown that the majority of Christians would be happy to talk about their faith with other people and to share their Christ-informed perspective on the Big Questions �?? but only �??if it comes up�??. Natural British reserve coupled with the traditional view that religious faith is a taboo topic at the dinner party table, have conspired to encourage Christians to keep their heads down and their faith private.

 

What is needed, what advertising can provide, and what the atheist campaign opens the door toward, is a very public debate on the existence and nature of God. Faith in God (or, indeed, its opposite) cannot be sold from a billboard, but advertising can create a context in which �??it comes up�?? more often, and in which one-to-one conversations �?? the virus of faith �?? can flourish.

 

Christians need to be able to respond appropriately. That may mean developing their own on-going ad campaign, comprising engaging, thought-provoking, biblically-sound advertising concepts rooted in human experience. But it will also mean engaging respectfully, constructively and appropriately to the God-conversations when they come up.

 

If they can do that, they may end up having a lot to thank atheist buses for.



Mike Elms is a Fellow of The Marketing Society and a management consultant specialising in the advertising and marketing sector. He was formerly Chief Executive of ad agencies Ogilvy & Mather and Tempus/CIA.


        

    








    105


Jump to Latest
    Comment 

    The debate



    

    
        
                
                
                    
                        Nicholas
                    
                        3 Nov
                    
                    
                        
Much muddle in this article.

Water and electricity, for example, are generic products. The token competition in the energy market has not increased demand for electricity. The absurd competition between expensive and inefficient bottled water and indistinguishable tap water has not increased consumption of water.

Where is this "research" that shows that we are unhappier than in, say, 1850, when women frequently died in childbirth, and children frequently died young?

Which are the "Big Questions"? Are they the silly "Who am I?", "Why am I here?" and, forsooth, "Where am I going?", to all of which there are obvious answers, and on none of which the historical or legendary Jesus offered any "perspective". (Except, possibly, the historical Jesus's delusion that his comtemporaries were about to see the End of the World and the Coming of his "Kingdom".)

Or is it the existence and nature of god(s)? I agree that "There's probably no God" on a few buses might, just might, start a few conversations at the bus stop. But I can't see it starting a "very" (as opposed to slightly?) public debate. Hope I'm wrong: can't wait to see some "biblically-sound advertising concepts rooted in human experience". Examples, please. And will there be Koranically-sound and Book-of-Mormonically sound competition?


                    
                

            
                
                
                    
                        Nicholas
                    
                        3 Nov
                    
                    
                        
PS: Hope we get rival campaigns on the lines "It's only Y_hw_h's grace that stops you from being a serial rapist", and "After your death, you'll be judged on your good works, if any."


                    
                

            
                
                
                    
                        Zak Bishrey
                    
                        3 Nov
                    
                    
                        
Nicholas: I think you are being rather hard on Mike. He is a specialist in marketing and knows only too well that advertising in clever hands will do wonders to a product, whether it is Christianity or margarine that you can�??t tell from butter. It is the copywriter�??s art that persuades people to spend millions on a �??moisturiser�??, not because it is jellified water but because they have been bludgeoned into believing that �??they are worth it�??.


Nevertheless, I am a little surprised that Mike should employ the same technique on a forum visited by such as Nicholas and Greywizard, as he does on a marketplace populated by plebs! Apart from that, my only beef with the bus is that it exhibits the word �??Probably�??. In engineering, if the probability is considerably less than one in a trillion, then it is safely considered to be zilch.





                    
                

            
                
                
                    
                        Greywizard
                    
                        3 Nov
                    
                    
                        
I agree with Nicholas that there is plenty of muddle in Mike's article, but the real muddle starts right at the beginning, when he disingenuously thanks Dawkins for opening up a discussion on the reasons for religious belief. Hoping to silence the so-called new atheism in its tracks, Christians keep issuing the warning that nothing has helped them more than the militancy of atheism. Yea, sure, that's why they're so strident right back.



In a straight up discussion religions will lose, every time. It's only when they start pulling the authority card - as Mike does in speaking about the rather odd-sounding biblically-sound advertising slogans (this must be a first!) - that they start to win - well, so long as people are trained to respond to it.



There are no respectable critical arguments in favour of religion and religious beliefs. You can tell this because at this point religious people always bring up the bogus questions: Who am I? Why am I here? Where do I come from? These are not real questions. They are types of obfuscation, well-known to religious apologists. (This is, by the way, the whole premise of the Alpha course. Everyone is walking around with a burden of these questions, and, of course, Christianity of a rather lacklustre character, has all the answers. Who knew?!) If you can bamboozle someone into thinking that these are real questions, you might get a bit of mileage out of them, but it's a pretty hard sell just now.



That's why people whip out the 'C of E' tag when religion is mentioned. It's easier than discussing ideas they find slightly embarrassing. Why does Mike think that the C of E is the church that most people stay away from? Mike may be an advertising expert, but I don't think he can sell his holy water. On the other hand, the atheist adverts may have some leverage. It might help people to see that they are not alone.



As to the word 'probably', Zak. This is really the only option for someone of purports to be critical. Proofs of non-existence are hard to come by. But, I agree, they could use 'very probably' instead, or something like, 'There is an extremely low probability that there is a god.' Of course, it's a gentle introduction to scepticism. Give it time. It will come.


                    
                

            
                
                
                    
                        Paul Rodden
                    
                        3 Nov
                    
                    
                        
I'm with GreyWiz, Nicholas, and Zak, on this one so far...


As to the phrase, "thought-provoking, biblically-sound", the people I know who are 'biblically sound', are often, sadly, thought-provokingly challenged.


                    
                

            
                
                
                    
                        Nicholas
                    
                        3 Nov
                    
                    
                        
Ariane Sherine has put on record her reason for the 'probably': to be sure of not flouting the advertising code.

It is, by the way, often possible to prove non-existence. Once you've defined integers, you can prove that there is no pair of integers such that the square of one is double the square of the other. And it is certain that there is no human that can fly without any mechanical aid. And it is certain that there is no omnipotent entity which cares about the continual suffering of most life-forms on this planet. There could however be any number of preternatural entities that enjoy suffering, or haven't got enough powers to limit it on this planet.

Zak: I take it that your question about which God is mentioned on the bus is a sincere question about how believers account for religious pluralism? I ask this because most blogs seem to be full of men (I'm not being sexist here, bloggers do seem to be mostly male, especially when the subject is God) who are only interested in scoring intellectual points off other men who disagree with them; if this is the case please ignore my comments, as I'm sure you are probably much cleverer than me. Still, assuming that you are sincere, maybe I can just sketch very roughly some kind of answer.





Believers down the centuries have not been blind to the existence of different ideas of God, and have dealt with the issue of the plurality of gods in three main ways. Exclusivists say that their god is the only one, and all the others are false. Inclusivists say that, whilst theirs is the truest religion, there is truth in others too, and maybe God saves through these other religions. For Pluralists, saying your religion is the best is equivalent to saying that your mum is the best mum in the world, (of course she is, she yours) and that all religions can be different ways to God, some truer than others maybe, but all capable of 'saving' in so far as the religion fosters a true relationship with God.





There have been advocates of all these positions in all the major religions for centuries, though it is probably true to say that the semitic religions have been much more exclusivist generally. Muslims have traditionally regarded Jews and Christians as fellow believers; indeed in some traditions, anyone who belives in a holy book is a believer. I think also you'll find that most devout Jews do not regard everyone else as damned; in fact the rabbis long ago rejected the idea of Hell. There are of course Exclusivists in all the religions; I have a feeling that it's only the logic of their position which stops some atheists from consigning believers to Hell. 





However, lots of valuable work has been done by Christian theologians in more recent times; if you are interested in a pluralist account of religion which has won widespread multi-faith acclaim, try 'An Interpretation of Religion' by John Hick.





I'm sorry if these remarks seem very simplistic, I do realize they are, and Hick says it much better.

A cop out.


Then came the bag bang theory which troubled me even more than the steady state model, not only because it requires a creator, and the negation of all established physical laws, but it is also impossible to see exactly what it was that banged. For if the stuff of the universe was baryonic confined in a singularity, then it could not have banged for obvious reasons. But if the stuff of the universe before the bang was non-baryonic then it would have required an external force (a god) to confine it in a tiny space in the first instance, and then for this or a rival god to pull the trigger and release the stuff into a mushrooming universe. In either case there is a need to pretend that the physical laws never existed at one time or another, and a necessity for a magician to produce a rabbit out of a hat. A cop out.


I have read heaps of literature produced by the supporters and detractors of the steady state and the big bang, and find (in my humble opinion) that both camps are barking up the wrong tree. My model does not require a creator, nor a bang, nor any variable constants, nor setting aside any established physical laws, nor the creation of time, nor the endless fiddling with the background temperature of outer space to suit the endless morphing of the big bang model. My model satisfies Hubble�??s expansion of the universe without the need for a bang, and it is based partly on Planck�??s four constants and, crucially, on the contention that the sum of all the vectors of existence of any stuff in the universe, whether baryonic or non-baryonic, must be zero. If this treads on any god�??s tail then tough.

I still think that non-existence can sometimes be proved. I'd like the buses to say "There aren't any benevolent omnipotent entities."

Integers are part of every day experience. As I said before, there is proof that there is no pair of integers such that the square of one is exactly double the square of the other. (7 and 5 are a near miss: 49 is nearly double 25.) There is proof that Sherlock Holmes did not exist: his invention, as a fictional character, is documented. Amusingly, given that Conan Doyle was taken in by faked photographs of fairies, it would likewise (in principle although, I agree, not in practice) be possible to trace each tale of fairies or unicorns or mermaids to its inventor or faker, and thus show that there are no fairies at the bottom of my garden, or anywhere else. If it is asserted that there is an actual teapot in a stated orbit around the sun, it is in principle possible to send a probe to show that it isn't there. The trouble comes, as Russell pointed out, when the teapot is thereupon said to be invisible. And it gets worse when the teapot was once cracked, but is now whole, and forgives sins, and children are schooled to sing hymns to it which have damned good tunes.

Sadly, even though Joseph Smith's brazen invention of a new god is well documented, millions of people were and still are fooled by it.

Once upon a time, the last of the dinosaurs suffered as they watched their children starve to death in the face of we know not what calamity. That fact, and countless similar miseries, prove that there are no benevolent omnipotent entities. The writer(s) of Job knew that, and described a malevolent, prodigiously powerful (but less than omnipotent) god.

Of course I know that there are books, too many books, and all too long, which attempt to devise so-called theodicies that will open a crack for a benevolent omnipotent entity to creep in. They all fail, because they all postulate either a less than omnipotent entity, or a malevolent entity which can't distinguish between bearable formative suffering and unbearable destructive pain.

At the same time that someone like Bishop Spong turns the scriptures upside down, and concludes that they do not mean what Christians believe they do, he still leaves the scriptures in place as a protected work, and protected works like the Bible have ways of unaccountably breaking out in proxsysms of organismic violence. They have a way of intruding themselves into the public conversation in ways that are simply dangerous, and are to be avoided at all costs.



Christians are free to indulge their beliefs, if they wish. Religions may, perhaps, even enhance the lives of practioners, but when religion begins to spill over, as  religion, into political contexts, then we have trouble, because religions still refuse to deal with the danger of sacred text. I suspect that this cannot be done, and that religions will always be a danger to women, gay and lesbian person, children and others, who, for historical reasons, stand outside the normative society constructed by most religious texts. I am reminded here of something that President elect Obama said in an address back in 2006. After talking about the important place of religion in people's lives, he goes on in this vein.




"Democracy demands that the religiously motivated translate their concerns into universal, rather than religion-specific, values. It requires that their proposals be subject to argument, and amenable to reason. I may be opposed to abortion for religious reasons, but if I seek to pass a law banning the practice, I cannot simply point to the teachings of my church or evoke God's will. I have to explain why abortion violates some principle that is accessible to people of all faiths, including those with no faith at all."



That, it seems to me is very important, and well said. Nor do I think that René Girard's ideas about the way ritual sacrifice functions as a kind of cathartic ritual for real social violence will do the trick here. I'm not even convinced that Girard's theory is right, though it has been given a lot of mileage in the last decade or two. Religions, it seems to me, need to stop pretending that violence sourced in religion can help spilling over into the public realm. There have been too many children who have died in the US, for example, for want of simple medical procedures, to make even a modest restrictions of religious violence to the private sphere enough. Religions need to begin acknowledging the violence which lies at the heart of religious texts. It's a problem that needs to be faced. And then they need to demote the texts themselves as sources of ultimate authority. Everyone I talk to thinks of Christianity as a religion of peace and love. Okay, let it be that, and let it take the texts in the New Testament that preach hatred of those who differ in belief and condemn heretics to hellfire, and say that they no longer have, or should be considered to have, divine authority. They should not have to be explained away; they should simply be expurgated. Christianity must take the texts that derogate from dignity of women and do likewise, and so for other religions. When they have done that, shorn their texts of authoritative violence, then perhaps they can say with some show of reason that they can be powers for good within society. But until they have done that, they remain dangers, suffused with violence that will break out, with unexpected fury from time to time; and society will continue to suffer from kinds of violence that religious people say, with some show of reason, that they do not themselves endorse, and yet retain unmonitored in their texts, awaiting the next champion who believes he has suddenly found the truth of faith that his fellow believers have missed or have been unfaithful to all these years.



The blood of Aisha Ibrahim Duhulow cries out from the ground, and more blood will be spilt, unless religious people acknowledge the violence that lurks at the heart of their religious texts.



Of course, what I say refers not only to religious texts or religious contexts. I am far away from thinking that only religion is to be blame. Any absolute ideology is the same. Any ideology that cannot take individuals and their good into consideration is exactly the same, and there have been enough atheist ideologies to make it clear that it is not religion itself that need be at fault. It just usally is, in the world that we know. But religion could, if it wished, be a purely benign force in the world. It could translate its message into one of peace, respect for persons, and a dedication to those who need help. It could funnel billions of pounds or dollars into doing these things, instead of wasting it on buildings erected to worship a God that is worshipped too much in hatred and separation. For what has God to do with rivers of oil, or cases of wine, or the fat of rams? What does God require of you but to do justly and love mercy and walk humbly with God? The blood of Aisha Ibrahim Duhulow and her sisters and brothers cries out from the ground.

title: North Wales Regional Committee
text:
North Wales Regional CommitteePWYLLGOR RHANBARTH Y GOGLEDD 
 
Adroddiad i'r Cynulliad 2003-04 
 
1. Cyflwyniad 
 
1.1 Mae Pwyllgor Rhanbarth y Gogledd yn un o bedwar o 
bwyllgorau rhanbarth y Cynulliad. Mae'n cynnwys Conwy, Sir 
Ddinbych, Sir y Fflint, Ynys Môn, Wrecsam a'r ardal o Wynedd sy'n 
cynnwys hen ardaloedd Arfon a Dwyfor. 
 
1.2 Rhwng mis Gorffennaf 2003 a mis Mawrth 2004, cadeiriwyd y 
Pwyllgor gan Janet Ryder. Aelodau eraill y Pwyllgor yw Eleanor 
Burnham, Mark Isherwood, Alun Ffred Jones, Ann Jones, Denise 
Idris-Jones, Ieuan Wyn Jones, John Marek, Sandy Mewies, Alun 
Pugh, Carl Sargeant, Karen Sinclair and Brynle Williams. Mae'r 
Arglwydd Dafydd Elis Thomas yn Aelod ond nid yw'n mynychu 
cyfarfodydd gan mai ef yw'r Llywydd. 
 
1.3 Cyfarfu'r Pwyllgor bum gwaith rhwng mis Gorffennaf 2003 a 
mis Mawrth 2004.  Nodir y manylion yn Atodiad 1. 
 
2. Cylch Gwaith a Dull Gweithio 
 
2.1 Yn ôl Rheol Sefydlog 10.2, swyddogaeth y pwyllgorau 
rhanbarth yw cynghori’r Cynulliad Cenedlaethol ar faterion sy’n 
ymwneud â’u rhanbarthau, effaith polisïau’r Cynulliad ar y 
rhanbarthau hynny, a gwaith cyrff cyhoeddus yn y rhanbarthau. 
 
2.2 Yn ystod ei gyfarfod cyntaf, aeth y Pwyllgor ati i wahodd y 
cyhoedd i fynegi eu barn ar faterion i'w trafod yng nghyfarfodydd y 
dyfodol.  Daeth y cynigion yn sail rhaglen waith ar gyfer y 
flwyddyn, a ddaeth ar gael yn yr ail gyfarfod ac fe'i cyhoeddwyd ar 
wefan y Cynulliad.  
 
2.3 Roedd pwyslais y cyfarfodydd ar annog y cyhoedd i gymryd 
rhan, gydag ambell gyflwyniad er mwyn annog y drafodaeth.  Ar ôl 
pob cyfarfod, aeth y Pwyllgor ati i baratoi adroddiad yn crynhoi'r 
sylwadau a fynegwyd gan bobl Gogledd Cymru.  Cyflwynwyd 
copïau i'r Aelod Cynulliad, y pwyllgor neu'r awdurdod cyhoeddus 
perthnasol er mwyn iddynt gael ymateb i'r pwyntiau a godwyd.  
 
 12.4 Roedd llawer o aelodau'r cyhoedd yn bresennol trwy gydol y 
flwyddyn, gyda chyfartaledd o bron i gant yn mynychu cyfarfodydd 
ym Mhwllheli ac yn Llangollen.  Ar ôl derbyn cais gan un o'r 
cyhoedd, cynhaliwyd cyfarfod peilot gyda'r nos ac argymhellwyd i'r 
Pwyllgor Busnes y dylid diwygio Rheolau Sefydlog y Cynulliad er 
mwyn caniatáu i'r Pwyllgor gyfarfod gyda'r nos ddwywaith y 
flwyddyn (allan o gyfanswm o chwe cyfarfod). 
 
2.5 Mae'r Pwyllgor wedi parhau'n ymrwymedig i fynd ati mewn 
modd cynhwysol o weithio.  Cynhaliwyd cyfarfod ymhob un o 
ardaloedd awdurdodau lleol Gogledd Cymru mewn lleoliadau yr 
oedd modd eu cyrraedd drwy ddefnyddio trafnidiaeth gyhoeddus.  
Ceisiwyd sylwadau gan Fforymau Mynediad i'r Anabl cyn y 
cadarnhawyd lleoliadau'r cyfarfodydd. Defnyddiwyd gwasanaethau 
palanteipydd yn nau gyfarfod olaf y flwyddyn, a derbyniwyd 
adborth cadarnhaol gan y rhai a oedd yn drwm eu clyw. 
 
3.  Gweithgareddau 2003-04 
 
3.1 Yn ystod y cyfnod sydd dan sylw, ystyriwyd y materion 
canlynol yn y cyfarfodydd ffurfiol:  
 
• Rheoli gwastraff; 
• Ymchwiliad Pwyllgor yr Amgylchedd, Cynllunio a Chefn 
Gwlad i'r agweddau cynllunio sy'n ymwneud â thai 
fforddiadwy a chymunedau cynaliadwy yng nghefn gwlad; 
• Adolygiad o Gynllun Datblygu Cynaliadwy y Cynulliad; 
• Y system gynllunio ac ariannu newydd ar gyfer addysg ôl-16 
yng Nghymru; 
• Masnach Deg, er mwyn cyd-fynd â Phythefnos Masnach 
Deg 2004. 
 
3.2 Estynnwyd gwahoddiad i'r Gweinidog dros yr Amgylchedd, 
Cynllunio a Chefn Gwlad gan y Pwyllgor i fynychu'r cyfarfod a 
oedd yn ystyried yr adolygiad o Gynllun Datblygu Cynaliadwy'r 
Cynulliad.  O ganlyniad, ysgrifennodd Cadeiryddion Pwyllgorau 
Rhanbarthol at y Prif Weinidog yn awgrymu y dylid ymestyn yr 
arfer hon i bob pwyllgor rhanbarthol. 
 
3.3 Yn ogystal â'r cyfarfodydd cyhoeddus ffurfiol, cynhaliwyd 
sesiwn friffio anffurfiol gydag Awdurdod Heddlu Gogledd Cymru i 
drafod goblygiadau eu trefniant ariannol ar gyfer yr ardal. 
 
 24.  Blaenraglen 
 
4.1 Yn y cyfarfod diwethaf, awgrymwyd y dylai un o gyfarfodydd y 
dyfodol ystyried argaeledd gofal mewn hosbis yng Ngogledd 
Cymru. Argymhellais y dylai'r Pwyllgor barhau gyda'r arfer o 
wahodd y cyhoedd i awgrymu pynciau i'w trafod yn ystod y 
flwyddyn. 
 
 
Janet Ryder AC 
Mai 2004
 3 
DYDDIAD / PWNC YN BRESENNOL ADRODDIAD   CANLYNIAD 
LLEOLIAD 
 
4 Gorffennaf 2003 Rheoli gwastraff 8 o Aelodau'r Roedd adroddiad 1 yn codi Ymatebodd y Gweinidog dros yr 
 Pwyllgor pryderon am argaeledd dulliau Amgylchedd i'r pwyntiau cyffredinol 
NEWI, Wrecsam  cynaliadwy o reoli gwastraff a a wnaed yn yr adroddiad. 
36 o Aelodau'r gofynnwyd am fwy o

 ei ddefnyddio fel sylfaen i'r broses 
Anfonwyd yr adroddiad at y graffu ar gynnydd er mwyn bodloni 
Gweinidog dros yr Amgylchedd, targedau rheoli gwastraff Yn Gall 
Cadeirydd yr Amgylchedd, Gyda Gwastraff, yn enwedig 
Cynllunio a Chefn Gwlad (EPC), a targedau 2003-04 ar gyfer 
Chyngor Gwynedd. targedau ailgylchu a chompostio.

ymholiadau penodol a godwyd gan 
aelod o'r cyhoedd. 
 
3 Hydref 2003 Ymchwiliad 5 o Aelodau'r Amlygodd Adroddiad 2 yr angen i Diolchodd Cadeirydd Pwyllgor yr 
 Pwyllgor yr Pwyllgor gynnal cymunedau cynaliadwy Amgylchedd, Cynllunio a Chefn 
Neuadd Dwyfor, Amgylchedd,  mewn ardaloedd gwledig, a'r Gwlad i'r Pwyllgor ac i'r cyhoedd 
Pwllheli Cynllunio a Chefn 137 o Aelodau'r materion penodol yr oedd hwn yn am yr adroddiad, a gyfrannodd at 
Gwlad i'r Cyhoedd ei godi mewn rhai ardaloedd yng ymchwiliad Pwyllgor yr 
agweddau Ngogledd Cymru.   Amgylchedd, Cynllunio a Chefn 
cynllunio sy'n  Gwlad.

			CITY FANS URGED TO RUN FUNDRAISERS FOR FRED KEENOR »

		


		
			
				
						
							
								Apr
								24
								2010
							

						

						
					
				

				Bucket collection for Keenor statue appeal

				
Posted by admin in Trust News				

			


			


A BUCKET collection for the Fred Keenor Statue Fund will be held at the Cardiff City Stadium before the home leg of the Semi-Final Play-Off game.

The Bring a Pound to the Ground – And More collection is being organised by members of the statue fundraising committee.

Statue project manager David Craig is appealing for fans coming to the game to volunteer as collectors by contacting him on d.craig43@ntlworld.com. They will need to be at the ground 90 minutes before the game – either on Saturday, May 8th, or on Tuesday/Wednesday of the week following to begin collecting inside the stadium.

David Craig, Cardiff City Supporters’ Trust Board member, said: “We know that money is tight because of the economic situation. But we hope supporters will give generously – at least £1 from every adult would be great, but more if they you can afford it.

“We need 14 volunteers to help collect donations for this very worthwhile cause so I would be grateful if they could get in touch as soon as possible.”



				
					
This entry was posted on Saturday, April 24th, 2010  at 9:43 am and is filed under Trust News. You can follow any responses to this entry through the RSS 2.0 feed. Both comments and pings are currently closed.

docs.description: 40. TO THE EDITORIAL BOARD OF PRAVDA
title: Lenin: 40. TO THE EDITORIAL BOARD OF PRAVDA
text:
Lenin: 40. TO THE EDITORIAL BOARD OF PRAVDA

    
      V. I.  

      Lenin


    40


    To:   THE EDITORIAL BOARD OF PRAVDA


    


    

      

	Written: Written not earlier than May 25, 1913 


	Published:

      First published in 1933 in Lenin Miscellany XXV.

      Sent to St. Petersburg.

      Printed from the original.

      
Source:

      Lenin
	  Collected Works,

      Progress Publishers,

      [1976],

      Moscow,

      Volume 35,

      pages 99-100.

      
Translated: Andrew Rothstein

      
Transcription\Markup:
R. Cymbala

      
Public Domain:

      Lenin Internet Archive.  

      You may freely copy, distribute,
	display and perform this work, as well as make derivative and
	commercial works. Please credit “Marxists Internet
	Archive” as your source.

      
Other Formats:  
Text
	• README

    


    


    

 


Dear Colleagues,



Today at last I have received the file of Pravda for the
last few days or, more precisely, for the last week. My best
thanks and best congratulations on your success: in my
opinion the paper has now undoubtedly found its feet.
The improvement is a tremendous one and a serious one,
and, let us hope, firm and for good. The length of
Plekhanov’s articles and the abundance of anti-liquidationism
(about which one of the workers’ deputies writes to me) are
now questions of detail; it won’t be difficult to correct
matters in Ibis respect, now that the paper has taken a firm
stand, and I think that the workers on the spot will see at
once bow to make the necessary correction. We have also
received the detailed letter of a member of the staff (who
unfortunately has not the pleasant “deputy” quality), and
we were very glad of it, congratulating him on every kind
of success. It seems as though now (and only now, after
the
St—v[1]

adventure) the period of wavering has ended ...
touch wood!...



I don’t advise you to present Plekhanov with ultimatums:
it is too early, it may do harm!! If you do write to him,
write as kindly and mildly as possible, He is valuable
now because he is fighting the enemies of the working-class
movement.



As regards Demyan Bedny, I continue to be for. Don’t
find fault, friends, with human failings! Talent is rare.
It should be systematically and carefully supported. It
will be a sin on your conscience, a great sin (a hundred

    

times bigger than various personal “sins”, if such occur...)
against the democratic working-class movement, if you
don’t draw in this talented contributor and don’t help
him. The disputes were petty, the cause is a serious one.
Think over this!



As regards expansion, I have recently written in detail
to one of the Prosveshcheniye people; I hope you also have
seen the letter. I, too, am in favour of financial caution:
to provide the same six pages (the present extra sheets) in
another form, with a different sauce and title and content:
4 pages of Sunday supplement for the advanced workers + 2
pages of a “workers’ kopek” for 1 kopek, for the masses,
to win a hundred thousand readers, with an especially
popular content. You shouldn’t imitate Luch but go your
own road, the proletarian road: 4 pages for the advanced
workers and 2pages (and later even 4)
for the masses, for a
long and stubborn battle for 100,000 readers. We must go
wide and deep, into the masses, and not follow intellectual
patterns like Luch.



Once again greetings, congratulations and best wishes.



Yours,

 V. I.



Another special greeting to Vitimsky: his article about
the workers’ press and workers’ democracy against
the
liberals[2] was very successful!! And the Bogdanov “Ideology”
is certain to heresy: I promise you that I will prove this
exactly!![3]



Marxists are glad of an increase in circulation when it
is increased by Marxist articles, and not by articles against
Marxism. We want a principled paper—all the contributors
and readers of Pravda want it—a Marxist, not Machist
paper? Isn’t that so?



P.S. The address is not Paronen, but Poronin (Galizien),
and be sure to add on the wrapper: via Warsaw-Frontier–
Zakopane.


     

    


    Notes


     



 [1]

 Who this refers to has not been established.—Ed.


     






[2]

Lenin refers to the article by M. S. Olminsky (A. Vitimsky) “Kto s
kem?” (“Who Is on Whose Side?”), published in Pravda No. 106,
May 10, 1913. The article was part of the polemic with Luch
concerning the conference between the editors of bourgeois
publications and representatives of the workers’ press. The conference
was called for the purpose of protesting at the introduction of
harsher laws against the press. The chairman of the conference did
not allow a vote on the draft resolution submitted by the Pravda
representatives. They and representatives of a number of trade
union papers refused to sign the liberal editors’ resolution.
Besides the representatives of Rech, Russkaya Molva, Sovremennoye
Slovo and Dyen, etc., =

only the representatives of Luch and Nasha
Zarya signed the resolution, thus acting against the workers’
papers represented at the conference.









[3]

On Lenin’s insistence A. A. Bogdanov’s article “Ideology” (from
the “Dictionary of Foreign Words” series) was rejected by Pravda
as anti-Marxist. Concerning the statement which Bogdanov then
sent to Pravda announcing his resignation from the paper, Lenin
wrote a “Letter to the Editor” which was published in the
newspaper Put Pravdy No. 9, January 31, 1914 =

(see present edition, Vol. 
20, pp. 93–94).




    

    


    
      	
	      <
		  backward
	    	 	
	      forward

title: A view from Rural Wales: Well Done Russell
text:
A view from Rural Wales: Well Done Russell









skip to main  |
      skip to sidebar






A view from Rural Wales





Welsh politics and countryside





















          
        
Tuesday, July 15, 2008


          
        




Well Done Russell








Not often that a new young councillor pulls off a big score. But new Powys Conservative Councillor, Russell George did just that today. The Council was considering a proposal to sell off the old Market Hall in Newtown, Montgomeryshire, which in my and Russell's opinion would have been a failure to show reasonable responsibility towards the 36 Market Traders who run businesses from there. Well, Russell managed to persuade a majority of the Council's Executive Board to back him. Any decision to dispose has now been deferred until a planning application by Tesco, which is currently being considered, has been decided. I'm not sure what the thinking is behind this. Perhaps, Tesco may be 'persuaded' to pick up some of the cost of maintaining the Market Hall. Who knows. But it was a great decision.

I was very surprised to hear that the Liberal Democrat members of the Executive Board didn't support Russell, and the Market Traders of Newtown -  despite the Market Hall being in the ward of a Lib Dem Councillor. I understand Montgomeryshire's MP, Lembit Opik had also been in touch with the traders. The Lib Dem councillors seem to have totally ignored both of them. Interesting - and especially so for the Market Traders. Anyway, lets hear it for Councillor Russell George - a man who gets things done.







Posted by
Glyn Davies


at
18:05











































13
comments:
        



	








Dr. Christopher Wood
said...

	

Here here



	


Tue Jul 15, 07:26:00 PM

said...

	

The Liberal Democrats have lost the plot in Montgomeryshire and this is just another example



	


Tue Jul 15, 09:28:00 PM








	







Anonymous
said...

	

... 'hook, line and sinker' ... so let's keep them in our prayers!



	


Tue Jul 15, 10:27:00 PM

said...

	

Glyn, I'm surprised that you know so much considering that the report was confidential? however it was not only Russell that deserves praise but the other Newtown Members namely, Cllrs White,Mills,Torrens & Harris. It was a classic example of Cllrs working for the good of the people and not the party? I know I was there.



	


Tue Jul 15, 11:02:00 PM








	








Glyn Davies
said...

	

Gary - I'm disappointed if I've said anything that I shouldn't, because I didn't intend to. I'll check tomorrow, and apologise if its appropriate. 
In fact a majority of the Board behaved responsibly (in my opinion) and deserve praise.  Its just that I know that Russell had been in discussions about this issue with the Market Traders last week, and involved me in the discussions. Also, he's the only one of the names you refer to who is a member of the Board. And I only blog about what I know.



	


Tue Jul 15, 11:28:00 PM








	







Anonymous
said...

	

Thank goodness the Lib Dems won't be representing us in parliament after the next election.  They KNOW they are going to loose the seat to you as long as Opik represents them.  And they are too cowardly to get rid of him.  Even though he's doing them untold damage on a daily basis - witness the farce being played out at the moment.  All of our family used to vote for them.  After this week, none of us will.  We're with you now Glyn



	


Wed Jul 16, 12:22:00 AM








	







Valleys Mam
said...

	

Ive been to the market Glyn and its a real local market .I am delighted its not being abandoned. 
What were they going to do with it - flats or a tescos !



	


Wed Jul 16, 08:09:00 AM








	








Glyn Davies
said...

	

anon - thanks for the encouragement.  It would be a huge honour and pleasure to represent you.

VM - I don't know precisely what the 'best offer' had in mind. I'd heard that it could be a Wetherspoons or a food retailer. I suspect it could easily have been a developer spotting an opportunity, in which case the offer would have been subject to some caveats.  What I would like to see would be aquisition by the Mid Wales Food and Land Trust, who were too late showing an interest, but now will hav etime to develop their ideas.



	


Wed Jul 16, 08:22:00 AM








	







Sarah Millington
said...

	

Glyn - I like Gary and Russell attended yesterdays board meeting and I have to say I agree, Cllr George made his point regarding the Market Hall, he made it well, so well that his comments may of been what persuaded a few other board members who were perhaps on the fence regarding the issue. I also agree with Gary when he says Cllrs White, Mills, Harris and Torrens also gave what can only be described as heartfelt pleas for the Market Hall. Well Done to all of them, they did as Gary rightly points work hard yesterday for the benefit of their electorate.



	


Wed Jul 16, 12:16:00 PM








	







gary price
said...

	

Glyn, You may like to have a look a Russell's posting of Newtown Market on his blog? He rightly points out the fact that all the Newtown Cllrs worked hard and left officers of the County Council red faced? The Independent Group Montgomeryshire & Labour Members also suppoted the retention of the Market it was the Powys Independant Alliance & Lib Dem Board Members that voted to sell it.



	


Wed Jul 16, 07:32:00 PM








	







Anonymous
said...

	

"... Gary - I'm disappointed if I've said anything that I shouldn't, because I didn't intend to. I'll check tomorrow ..." 

Just blame Edna Mopbucket for over indulging u.    

What's happened to Endna, you holding out of us Glyn?



	


Wed Jul 16, 09:14:00 PM








	








Glyn Davies
said...

	

Sarah and Gary - See you both tomorrow, unless something goes amiss. There is no disagreement twixt us at all Gary. I have checked and my comment that the Lib Dems opposed the plan to save the Markey Hall from closure was being broadcast widely. I heard it from several sources. The only point I didn't make is that if all the Lib Dems and Powys Independent Group/Alliance had vote, Russell would have lost the vote - so its clear that at least two of the Powys Independents did not support the sale option - simple arithmatic. 

Anon - I've got a feeling that Edna is bursting to give me some news - that I can publish that is.



	


Wed Jul 16, 10:34:00 PM








	







gary
said...

	

Glyn, Glad to have met you briefly today at County Hall, I was looking forward to talking to you at the end of the meeting however you had left before the end? Speak soon?

title: The diaries of Paul K Lyons - Oct1977
text:
The diaries of Paul K Lyons - Oct1977

	
		PIKLE   JOURNAL HOME PAGE   CONTACT

	

	
		Diaries
of
PAUL K LYONS

		1977

		January
February
March
April
May
June
July
August
September
October
November
December

	

	
		JOURNAL - 1977 - OCTOBER

		Sunday 3 October

		In the Abbey in Bath. How amazing is religion - so cold. I sit in a great mansion of grey stone - with enormous grey pillars where some man tried to reach the sky with painting his drawing on His building. Some man tried to reach god with his excellence, his splendour, his money. The roof of the church is high away with a concrete pattern of spiderwebs. It is all grey, except for the colour on the windows, the beautiful windows, which are exquisite and grand and multicoloured, all made for the His glory, and yet are still cold. A man plays on the organ, music by Haydn who spent years writing music to the glory of god. A priest reads the bible with a cold voice. The congregation sit and stand and sing and breathe without emotion. The choir sing because they like singing I suppose. It is frigid. The whole fucking thing is so frigid.

		Monday 4 October

		Well October is autumn. M returns closer and warmer. We are like children learning everything there is, learning to be free and to play.

		I am bored with my movement class. We are told to play games with our feet and communicate - such lovely feet you have Anne, such a lovely spine you have Pauline - but they are the games we play with our lovers any way.

		Tuesday 5 October

		I am here at 64 Carlton Hill with M and though we don't disturb much it is too much - two bodies grunting through the night, the whispering walls, the toilet flushes - so we have to find somewhere this week or the friction, the ugliness will be upon me.

		13 October

		THE IMPERIAL LIGHTHOUSE SERVICE

		In its heyday, the Imperial Lighthouse Service proudly owned 17 lighthouses in different parts of the grand British Commonwealth. The lighthouse keepers were solitary men returning once only every six months to homeland England. But those days have passed with the fading of our great empire. Just two are left, one off the Falkland Islands and the other somewhere in the Caribbean. They are maintained by the only four employees of the Imperial Lighthouse Service left in the world today. They are directed by the marine division of the Ministry of Trade in High Holborn. Some 69 men, though, are still receiving pensions from the Service. I would like to sing 'seventeen lighthouses of the Imperial Lighthouse Service' to the tune of ten green bottles, but it doesn't go very well.

		The Military and Orchestral Musical Instrumental Makers Trade Society has 160 members. The Amalgamated Association of Beamers, Twisters and Drawers has over 1,000 members.

		14 October

		I am sitting on M's bed looking out of our window watching the sun through the dense mass of leaves. It is like a pulsating star, as the eyes move ever so slightly so the sun flashes through a new aperture in the leaves. Around where the point sun shines brilliantly, the leaves are black, but further away from the point so the leaves become greener.

		17 October

		Days, words and feelings seem to get left behind at this time. Only by a conscious effort have I remembered some things from last night for instance. Without really knowing why I found myself at a concert given by Van de Graaf Generator. At the end of the concert, this long-haired freak started really shrieking his head around which was wonderful, a cool fresh breeze brushed by my own clammy heated head.

		M and I have moved into room 14, the Oakley Holiday Apartments, 93 Oakley St. tel no: 352 9970. Last night, for the first time in my life, I came home from work to find my woman in the kitchen making dinner. And for the first time in her life, she found herself waiting for her man to come home from work to eat dinner. M has problems with work as always, maybe she will take a job in a restaurant, and then we will never see each other.

		Jean-Christophe is a mixture of Italian, French, Swiss and English. He has been studying Reich body techniques, growth therapy, and is looking to start professional work in London. He came to me in Battersea Park when I was playing the recorder. He has a guru and meditates and is a vegetarian.

		19 October

		M and I were invited to dinner by Dad and his mistress.

		I played football in the park and kicked Stewart's ball into the lake. The ball floated around going here and there, but refusing to come to the side. Stewart and Martin watched and pleaded with the wind to blow it to the side. I tried to find a gardener and thought of the problem as an initiative test. Then Peter turned up with a man with wellingtons that reached to his breast. It was something I had not thought of - such gigantic wellingtons, it was very funny.

		I went to dinner with Peter and Tony - they are up and leaving to Germany to live in Bernau and maybe, maybe I can have their flat which is fantastic. There is a garden, a large front room, a bathroom, a kitchen, another little room and the living room - wow - let's wait and see.

		M said she would return after work, but, as yet, hasn't appeared.

		A beautiful letter arrives from N.

		21 October

		I cried some tears this morning because I realised what I had done, I had been hard, hard and cold, continually till M found herself weeping. I cried because I felt satisfied with that. Maybe it's good, I wonder now, maybe that is how it should be for M.

		I met a man named David, sitting alone writing a book on philosophy - on the essence of consciousness or some such thing. I suggested he step outside his work occasionally and look objectively at what he is doing, to think about the fact that some problems could stem from our mental language, and to read de Bono's 'Mechanisms of the Mind'. At least, for an hour or so, he stopped the gritty circulars in my head about the relationship with M.

		I am helping out a bit with the Latin America Festival.

		22 October

		Last night I saw a Bergmann film, 'The Silence'. It was about two sisters. One, called Esther, is dying and the other has a small boy. Esther is a writer, she is the quieter, more sedate, the passive, the thinker, and is in love with her sister, who is much more interested in a good time, making herself look good, going out, finding men. She is self-assured and hard. The latter was once very dependant on Esther but now finds herself completely independent of her and almost despising her. Esther is caught spying on her sister whilst making love with a stranger, and, in the ensuing argument, the sister accuses Esther: 'you're so damn full of self-importance'.

		I wonder if I identify with Esther. I tried to tie in this self-importance with the arrogance Mum accuses me of, and the totally different mental worlds M and I live in. I am always aware of what she might be doing, and very careful not to let her down, but she is blase, doing exactly what she wants even if it means I am put out somehow. But maybe what I have to understand is that she has no mental image in her mind that says I must go now or else I will be late and keep someone waiting, because she doesn't think of herself as that important. Here is my self-importance - the way I look at it, is that I am so important that everybody is thinking in terms of me, and that therefore I can't let anyone down.

		There's an organisation called The Screw, Nut, Bolt and Rivet Union.

		26 October

		Autumn is at its most beautiful. It is radiant in its colours, proud in its metamorphosis and high with the wind and change. Amersham found me sailing in a wood, breaking sticks, skipping, trying to play like a child but finding my playmate more interested in poisonous mushrooms. There was a tiger in the forest, a very dangerous tiger. I looked for it and killed it. And then I raced home to London, running from train to train, hating cities and communications and mixing it all with reading Genet and his beauteous pricks and brothel sex.

		'You see,' Jean said, 'there is a living force that connects everything, we are all energy and vibrations and there are forces that connect us. What you believe is that we have a computer brain and that we are all generic programmes.' 'Yes,' me speaking, 'absolutely birth and copulation and death, if we start talking about deeper levels and deeper feelings and contact with our centres etc. etc. could we just as easily say they are all programmes as well, programmes can be very complicated or very simple. On the other hand if we start talking about forces outside of us and something that isn't programmable within us then we must ask ourselves, maybe the all powerful Christian judging god can exist - if he can exist then we ought to do something about it.'

		M tells me now the Work was not going well when she left. I suggested maybe the Work was to blame, as I with Christianity. I always, but always, thought I was to blame for my lack of closeness to and understanding of god, but it wasn't, it was god's fault because he wasn't there. How could I tell that to M, that maybe she had overtaken the Work - had seen through it.

		Sometimes the moon can be seen through the trees from our window.

		On Saturday night I went to a party at Andre's house, I nearly didn't go, but M had been cold and I was a little bored. Anyway, at this party, was a girl called Judy Gardner. We'd met before, in New Zealand, when she picked me up hitchhiking. As a result of that meeting, she went on to take my job at Sandoz. So we spent half the night talking about Otago doctors! The other half I danced, smiling at some drama people and watching their little games as they interacted with mine.

		I was supposed to be organising one night of the theatre at the Oval but it turned out to be a full farce, with quarrels over timing and lights. The Chilean mime was very good, it was just two people, but with one woman doing 90% of the work. She really was excellent.

		It was good with M this week. I took everything as it came, and did my own thing, but M went sour on me still and we came back from the Yes concert in our tiny little shells until finally she talked of things that disturbed her calm.

		I am reading less, I am writing less, I am feeling definitely less, and I am smoking too much. It really is time to stop again, blah.

		'I have the key to happiness: remember, be profoundly profoundly, totally conscious that you are. I myself, sorry to say, hardly ever use this key. I keep losing it.' Eugene Ionesco  

		Paul K. Lyons

		November 1977

		 

		PIKLE   JOURNAL HOME PAGE   CONTACT

		Copyright © PiKLe PuBLiSHiNG

	

	
		1974 1975

		1976 1977

		1978 1979

		1980 1981

		1982 1983

		1984 1985

		1986 1987

		1988 1989

		1990 1991

		 

		2001 2002

		2003 2004
The diaries of Paul K Lyons - Oct1977

title: Local Action - East Anglia
text:
Local Action - East Anglia


East Anglia

By Trevor Garrod

Consultation pledge Anglia Railways Communications Manager Peter Meades was speaker at the summer meeting of the branch in Ipswich. As well as pointing to the company‘s achievements, he answered a wide range of questions, many about better links and more attractive fares between Cambridgeshire and the rest of the region. He promised consultation with rail users, including RDS, over the 1999 timetable.

The preserved Hastings diesel unit — a train built nearly 40 years ago to run inter-city services between London and Hastings — is currently based at Norwich and being used mainly to provide extra capacity on the routes to Yarmouth and Lowestoft. RDS members suggested this unique train be used to supplement Anglia‘s heavily used fleet.

Army on move During July, four military trains used the reopened line from Wymondham to Dereham, operated by our corporate member, the Mid Norfolk Railway Preservation Trust. Following a visit by the Railway Inspectorate, a number of minor jobs are being carried out prior to the reinstatement of a passenger service, planned for later this autumn.

View larger image

(Estimated download time 12 secs with a 56k modem)
























		


	Brief Description: Huntley & Palmers lorry transporting royal wedding cake, outside Buckingham Palace, at 11.00am on 28.07.81
	
	Subject Date: 28 July 1981
	





	 		




	Full Description: Huntley & Palmers produced cakes for royal weddings throughout the twentieth century. This cake was made for the marriage of the Prince of Wales and Lady Diana Spencer in July 1981. It was made by Stuart Munro and was four tiers in height. Huntley & Palmers, as part of Associated Biscuits, also produced two commemorative tins for the occasion.

	1:  	ICGC Goals, Structure, Policies and Guidelines Section E.3 - Publication Policy HTML

	to ensure appropriate dialogue between data users and generators and for authors to contact ICGC members and editors




    

  
  
  
  
  
  

                   
                       

              





              
                
                  Clinic & Pathology

                      


                

                 
    
  
  
      
             
	Biospecimen Core Resources (BCRs):
		United States: 	International Genomics Consortium
			The Research Institute at Nationwide Children's Hospital


    

  
  
  
  
  
  

                                    The Cancer Genome Atlas Biospecimen Core Resources are  centralized laboratories that review and process blood and tissue samples and their associated data using optimized standard operating procedures for the entire TCGA Research Network.

The work of the BCRs  include the following important functions:

• Serving as the interface between the TCGA program and the different Tissue Source Sites collecting tumor and matched normal controls

• Ensuring and verifying that TCGA human subjects protections and guidelines are adhered to and that all regulations are followed at each Tissue Source Site

• Including use of language consistent with the TCGA informed consent documents

• Examining of all biospecimens to ensure they meet rigorous standards for each tumor type (including percent necrosis and percent tumor nuclei)

• Reviewing of pathology to ensure accurate diagnosis and inclusion in TCGA

• Collecting clinical information for each tissue and applying standardized terminology, definitions and formats that are caBIG compliant

• Extracting DNA and RNA from tissue samples and and distributing to each of the genomic characterization and sequencing centers 



    
  
  
      
      

		
	1:  	Human Subjects Protection Guideline Documents HTML

	Genome Characterization Centers (GCCs):
		Canada: 	BC Cancer Agency
		United States: 	Baylor College of Medicine
			Brigham & Women's Hospital and Harvard Medical School

			University of North Carolina
			University of Southern California
	Genome Data Analysis Centers (GDACs):
		United States: 	Broad Institute
			Institute for Systems Biology
			Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory
			Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center
			University of California, Santa Cruz
			University of North Carolina
			University of Texas M. D. Anderson Cancer Center
	Genome Sequencing Centers (GSCs):
		United States: 	Baylor College of Medicine
			Broad Institute
			Washington University School of Medicine


    

  
  
  
  
  
  

 
                                  TCGA Genome Characterization Centers (GCCs) are responsible for characterizing all of the genomic changes found in the tumors studied as part of the TCGA program. The GCCs will use multiple platforms, including array technologies and second generation sequencing, to provide data to the cancer research community on alterations in miRNA and gene expression, single nucleotide polymorphisms and copy number changes.

TCGA Genome Sequencing Centers (GSCs) perform large-scale genomic sequencing using the most current technologies. The GSCs have the opportunity to continually improve existing technology and invest in implementation of new sequencing technologies to enable whole genome sequencing of tumors for complete genomic analysis at an increasingly reduced cost.

TCGA Genome Data Analysis Centers (GDACs) work with the Genome Characterization Centers to develop state-of-the-art tools that assist researchers with processing and integrating data analyses across the entire genome.

		United States: 	Broad Institute
	Data Coordinating Center (DCC):
		United States: 	NCI Center for Bioinformatics
			SRA International, Inc.
	Genome Data Analysis Centers (GDACs):
		United States: 	Institute for Systems Biology
			Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory
			Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center
			University of California, Santa Cruz
			University of Texas M. D. Anderson Cancer Center


    

  
  
  
  
  
  

                 The informatics component of TCGA involves developing best ways to collect, store, and distribute the clinical and genomic data generated by the project.

The Genome Data Analysis Centers work with the Genome Characterization Centers to develop state-of-the-art tools that assist researchers with processing and integrating data analyses across the entire genome.


                  
    
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  

                   

              

              
              



     
            

            
                            Project Summary

              The National Cancer Institute and the National Human Genome Research Institute launched The Cancer Genome Atlas program to create a comprehensive atlas of the genomic changes involved in more than 20 common types of cancer. This large-scale, high-throughput effort is being carried out by a network of more than 100 researchers at many organizations across the Unitred States. The overarching goal of TCGA is to further scientific understanding of the genomic changes in cancer, thereby improving the ability to diagnose, treat and prevent this devastating disease. All data generated by the TCGA research network are made rapidly available to the research community through the TCGA Data Portal.

              

                              Principal Investigators

title: Love relationships and sex
text:
Love relationships and sex
	






 


		
			
				
					
						
							
								
									
								

								
								| skip to main menu
								| skip to content |
								
									
									
									
										 
										
											hidden text

Search
										

											Help
	Site map


										 
										

									

									
									

								

								
								
									
										
											
												You are here:

												KCcentral
	Sports, health and lifestyle
	Sexual health and relationship
	Love relationships and sex


											

										

										
										
Love relationships and sex

									

									
								

								
								

							

							
							

						

						
						
							
								
Where to get advice

For free confidential advice on love, relationships and sex you
can contact:

	Sexwise: 0800
282 930
	Brook Helpline: 0800 0185 023
	Childline: 0800 11 11


Love

A crush becomes love when it becomes real – when you tell
someone how you feel and they feel the same way. But the object of
your passion may not know that you exist or how you feel. You
need to talk to find out if you have things in common and get to
know each other better.

So how can you tell if someone really likes you? Do they
talk to you, ask your opinion, listen to your answers, want to be
with you, treat you well? Respect is always a good place to
start. No good relationship can exist without it. So
anyone who avoids you, can’t remember your name, or is mean –
probably doesn’t love you!

Relationships

Relationships with other people, whether family, friends, or
others, are the most essential thing in our lives after food,
drink, shelter and warmth and can be the happiest moments that we
ever experience. But sadly, what we may want from relationships is
not always what we get.

For information about relationships or support dealing with
relationships that are hard, the teen issues website may
help. There are also the Beat bullying and Bullying websites that offer help
and information on this issue.

A good relationship is one where you can say you're friends. One
where you've got trust, respect, and can talk honestly to each
other and above all, be yourself.

If you’re looking for love and can’t find it, work on developing
friendships. People who make and maintain close friendships
learn valuable skills to apply next time for a different kind of
love.

Sex

What is sexual activity? This may include any activity that
sexually arouses you or your partner and might include talking and
flirting, kissing, looking, touching, stroking each other, kissing
using tongues, removing clothes, and touching each others
genitals. Sexual activity is not just about the penis
penetrating the vagina.

So what do people mean when they say they have had sex? They may
be referring to the above, or may be talking about penetrative sex
- when a vagina or anus is penetrated by a boy's penis, or oral sex
- when the mouth and tongue is used to pleasure and stimulate the
penis, vagina or anus.

If you can really feel good, relax and have fun together, then
when you are ready to have sex, the whole experience is likely to
be a much better one for both of you. Take your time and do
things only when you're ready.



What is the law on sex? The laws on sex are there to protect you
from abuse and to support people who do not wish to have sex before
they are ready. The law says it's legal for you to consent to
sexual relationships from the age of 16.

							

							
						

						
						
							
								
									Ask for advice

								
									If you need help and would like to talk to a personal advisor from Connexions, you
									can email them using KCcentral's electronic form.

		Badminton History
	

	
	
		All England Badminton Club
	



				
					
						All England Badminton  Club


						
							
								

The All England Badminton Club was founded on 24th October 1962 at a meeting at the Charing Cross Hotel, London.

The object of the club was to organise:- (a) at the All England Championships a club room where members can meet to renew old friendships and make new ones; (b) any other activity that appears desirable to the committee.

Full membership was to be open to the undermentioned on payment of the prescribed entrance fee:-

a) past and present International players of winners of an All England Championships:

b) past and present officers and councillors of the Badminton Association of England.

The committee could elect to honorary membership:-

(a) past and present internationals of any country affiliated to the International Badminton Federation.

(b) past and present officers and councillors of the International Badminton Federation.

(c) others at the discretion of the committee. (Such as official overseas visitors to the Championships).

The committee fixed the entrance fee at one guinea and produced a lapel membership badge which was based on a design by Allon Renton, who played for England 1948 to 1952 and was art master at a school in Winchester.

In 1962 the Badminton Association of England set aside a newly built lounge with a bar at Wembley during the All England Championships where drinks and light refreshments could be bought.

The entrance fee was to cover the cost of the badge and other expenses incurred in running the club. Ken Livingstone, a member of the committee writing in the Badminton Gazette in 1963 claimed that membership was growing steadily

The National Badminton Museum has a visitors’ book for the All England Badminton Club – dated 1996 when 28 members signed. It appears the book was put in a cupboard and forgotten as no other names or dates appear at all.

What has happened to the All England Badminton Club?
