title: St Mary Magdalene | Colwich Novitiate
text:
St Mary Magdalene | Colwich Novitiate

	
		
						
				
					Colwich Novitiate
				
			

			A glimpse into the life of a Benedictine novitiate

		


		
		  			Skip to content

							Home
	About us.
	Ben’ Resources
	Contact & find us
	Pets Page
	Q & A
	Timetable



		


		
						
									
							
					

	


	

		
			

			
				
					← Ora et Laboura.

					Jaimie’s formation. →

				


				
					St Mary Magdalene


					
						Posted on 22 July, 2008 by noviceship| 7 Comments
											


					
						Happy feast day of st mary magdalene – we all know who she was and what an inspiration she is. She reminds me that we are totally accepted and loved by Christ and that if we turn from the past – whatever it contains – we really can have new and vibrant life in Christ. I think she is awesome and would have chosen the name if I could have.

However, it is also Sr Mary Magdalen’s feast day, her first in community, and I would like to ask you all to join us in keeping her especially in your prayers today, and those who have also taken this name.

Today, Sr Mary Magdalen and I have been identifying a herb in our garden. Mother Anne said she thought it was St John’s Wort, but Sr Benedict thought not so out came Culpepper’s Herbal and a book on wildflowers and we identified it – it does help a lot that Sr is an artist so notices things that I don’t. It turns out that Sr Benedict was right – it is Loosestrife ( good for haemorrhage/bleeding in many forms ) not St John’s Wart. We had a nice time in recreation later looking at the Herbal and finding interesting uses for common things – did you know that you can stuff pieces of red beetroot up your nose to clear your head? Neither did we and it’s not something we are going to rush out and try, no it’s far nicer to eat instead. pax sr marie therese, St Mary Magdalene – pray for us.

											


					
						This entry was posted in Uncategorized. Bookmark the permalink.											

				


				
					← Ora et Laboura.

					Jaimie’s formation. →

				


				Like
Be the first to like this post.



	
	
			7 Responses to St Mary Magdalene


		
			
		
		
			
			Jaimie

			
				|
				
				22 July, 2008 at 4:16 pm
					|
					Reply								
		

		
		Happy Feast Day, Sister Mary Magdalen!:-) We have our own Sister Magdalen, so we celebrate with you both. It is our custom to offer all our prayers, works, joys, and sufferings of the day for a particular Sister on her feast day. Is there a similar custom in the Benedictine tradition?

Blessings, Jaimie(Postulant with The Sisters of the Third order of St. Francis, East Peoria, IL)




	


	
	
		
		
			
			noviceship

			
				|
				
				22 July, 2008 at 7:02 pm
					|
					Reply								
		

		
		Hi Jaimie,thanks for writing, I have just looked back at your community web site and found your blog too, both are great and I am putting a link on ours as I have enjoyed reading about your life and am going to keep on checking you out – I also think our bloggers will enjoy it too. I left a comment under your entry to the novitiate, again, many congratulations and prayers, I look forward to reading about it all in a few weeks and seeing what your new name is – Sr …?

Thankyou for your greetings to Sr Mary Magdalen, I will pass them on and she will probably read them too when she gets a chance, again, our greetings and blessings to your Sr Magdalen too.

     I don’t know if it is a general Benedictine custom to offer things up for the sister on her feast day but we do exactly that here too. A board with the sisters name on goes up outside chapel and we are asked to pray for her, Mass is also offerred for her and her intentions and she has a vase of flowers at her place in refectory which she takes up to her cell during the day. Sr Mary Magdalen usually does all the flowers as she is very artistic, and I should have done hers but I am not good with these things so had help from our novice mistress Mother Anne, she showed me and basically did the whole thing herself, I must learn though. pax et bonum, sr marie therese.




	


	
	
		
		
			
			Mary

			
				|
				
				23 July, 2008 at 12:37 am
					|
					Reply								
		

		
		Dear Sr. Marie-Therese and Sr. Mary Magdalen,

Happy feast day to you Sr. Mary Magdalen!  You will be in my prayers today – as you all are every day!  I am wondering if there are any special things done on a sisters feast day to celebrate?  A special recreation or does the sister have more prayer time or do you all bake her a cake!?  Or is it just another day with just best wishes extended or what?  I have always wondered what, if anything, is done in monasteries for the sisters feast days.  

I too have also found the herbs and plants and their medicinal uses fascinating.   But maybe you all want to rethink that about putting the red beetroot up your nose and be the first to document it for posterity!  Ha, only kidding!  It DOES sound very unpleasant!  But you have to wonder if it might not be better than a lot of the OTC meds on the shelves that don’t work at clearing your head!

Mary




	


	
	
		
		
			
			Mary

			
				|
				
				23 July, 2008 at 12:40 am
					|
					Reply								
		

		
		Dear Sr. Marie-Therese,

Sorry, I think I posted this at a time I didn’t hit the refresh button as your blog site was open on my computer for so long!  I you answered a lot of questions on the feast day in your response to Jaime!

Mary




	


	
	
		
		
			
			noviceship

			
				|
				
				23 July, 2008 at 4:30 am
					|
					Reply								
		

		
		Hi Mary, yes, at least the beetroot is natural and unless you are allergic to it – as one of our sisters is – shouldn’t have any nasty side effects. Culpeppers is wonderful – you probably know it if you are also interested in herbs – especially reading the ancient uses. It’s odd but it seems that loads of the herbs are diuretic and affect menstrual bleeding – the Loosestrife we found ( and have loads of ) does this so we won’t be making it into tea’s. I am going to start making raspberry leaf tea – for cramps – and drying some of the more common herbs for sister Teresa Mary ( I almost wrote my name, it sometimes gets confusing, and it’s your name too) to use in the kitchen. I also found a load of lovely Basil in the court. I think in the past the sisters must have been really into using herbs as there seem to be a lot of them growing all over the garden. pax sr marie therese.




	


	
	
		
		
			
			ursula

			
				|
				
				23 July, 2008 at 5:07 pm
					|
					Reply								
		

		
		My comp was down all Mon. PM & yesterday & I had to

use someone elses just to read my email b/c I was wait-

ing for Mothers reply which did indeed come, thanks be

to God! No comp today either but am not as rushed as

yesterday: Soooo, a very belated but Happy Feast Day!

You were in my thoughts & prayers even if not in the

blog….. I, too, like herbal remedies….Ursula




	


	
	
		
		
			
			noviceship

			
				|
				
				24 July, 2008 at 4:41 am
					|
					Reply								
		

		
		Ursula, thanks, I’m glad you are back on line and have got Mother’s email at last, thankyou for writing to me too,  I enjoyed reading your email and will back – time is always the factor here. Though we don’t go running around all the time and our busyness in no ways compares to working outside we do have set things at set times so have to fit things in. This week I am bell ringer again so I am constantly clock watching instead of just going at the sound of the bell.

   Herbal rememdies are good, I enjoy seeing what we can use but am not so good at identifying them so have to be very careful as I don’t want to poison anyone or myself. pax sr marie therese.

	Current location: Creativity and culture��>��Museums��>��City Museum and Art Gallery��>��Collections��>��Art collections��>��Decorative art��>��Silver


	
Silver

The silver collection comprises of local, civic silver from the 18th to the 20th century, including the presentation ���freedom boxes��� given to Lady and Viscount Astor in 1959 and 1936 respectively.

Two key pieces of silver in the collection are the Eddystone lighthouse salt and the Drake cup.

The Eddystone lighthouse salt is on display in the Plymouth, Port and Place gallery. It was made by Plymouth silversmith, Peter Rowe in 1698. It was commissioned to commemorate the building of Smeaton���s first lighthouse on the Eddystone reef and is thought to be the only representation of the very first lighthouse before changes were made to the lantern in 1699.

The Drake cup is on display at Buckland Abbey, home of Sir Francis Drake. The cup was thought to have been given to Drake by Queen Elizabeth I. It depicts a globe to celebrate his circumnavigation and was made by a Zurich silversmith in around 1571.

The south west had a thriving silversmith community in the 18th century and an assay office was set up in Exeter in 1700. The museum���s collection is representative of many of these silversmiths and holds examples from makers such as Pentecost Symons, Samuel Blatchford and Zacchariah Williams.

The museum also holds on loan a number of items of church plate from local churches. This includes some of the earliest existing pieces of ecclesiastical silver in the south west by John Jones of Exeter in 1575 who was commissioned to make communion cups after the Reformation in England.

29 July 2011

Children’s oral health gets Assembly committee check-up

The oral health of Welsh children will be examined in a new inquiry 
by the National Assembly’s Children and Young People Committee.

The Committee will focus on how effective the Welsh Government has been 
in improving children’s oral health, particularly in deprived areas where extra investment has been 
allocated.

Research shows the dental health of children in Wales is worse than 
in many other parts of the UK and rates of decay are much higher.

The most recent Child Dental Health Survey found that more than half 
of Welsh five-year-olds suffer dental decay and the problem is most prevalent in deprived areas.

The Welsh Government’s ‘Designed to Smile’ programme launched in 2009 
consisted of a supervised tooth brushing scheme for 3-5 year olds and a promotional programme for 6-11 
year olds.




“Given the level of investment the Welsh Government has dedicated to 
improving our children’s oral health, we feel it is time to examine how effective its efforts to improve 
standards have been,” said Christine Chapman AM, Chair of the Children and Young People Committee.

“Therefore we will be assessing whether that extra investment has delivered 
improved standards, particularly among children who live in Wales’s more deprived areas.

“We will also be asking what, if anything, can be done to ensure that 
Welsh children are getting the best possible service, consistently and across the country. 

“We would welcome the views and opinions of any individuals and organisations 
which have an interest in this inquiry.”

Anyone wishing to contribute to this inquiry can email submissions to 
CYPCommittee@wales.gov.uk, or, alternatively, write to—

Committee Clerk, Children and Young People Committee, National Assembly 
for Wales, Cardiff Bay, CF99 1NA.

title: A view from Rural Wales: Blue Language and a Red Face
text:
A view from Rural Wales: Blue Language and a Red Face









skip to main  |
      skip to sidebar






A view from Rural Wales





Welsh politics and countryside





















          
        
Thursday, March 29, 2007


          
        




Blue Language and a Red Face








I very rarely swear. And never in front of women and children. I'm a tad old fashioned about this - even though I understand that young women out on the town these days are much more foul-mouthed than young men. So today's occurrence was unfair in the extreme. Fate dealt me a poor hand.

For some reason, I've been feeling a bit down for a while and this morning had been a bit stressful. I'd been to the Newtown studio to do a piece for Post Cynta on our manifesto, which was to be launched at 10.30 in North Wales. Problem was that I hadn't read the final version, didn't know the lines we were going on - and it was in Welsh, which is a beautiful language but which I still find difficult. And Iolo ap Dafydd shows me no mercy these days. Anyway, I survived and was belting up to Northop for the launch, having asked my good friend, Brynle Williams for directions.

Problem was that Brynle's directions were duff. He sent me right instead of left. After a fruitless search for a promised set of crossroads, I rang BW on his mobile. No answer. Rang 4 times. No answer. Launch time approaching and now highly stressed. 5th call and Brynle answered. He hadn't even finished saying "Hello" when I .....how shall I put this......expressed my view of his directions, outlined displeasure at my predicament and suggested what he might do to help - but utilising words of variety and colour! It will not help my reputation if I record precisely what I said.

And just guess what Brynle said, and as cool as you like. "I'll come and collect you when I've dropped Cheryl Gillan and David Cameron off at the launch - and by the way my mobile is on open mike in the car." I felt a bit as the Earl of Oxford must have done when he farted in front of Queen Elisabeth 1st, and left the country for 10 years in shame. The only consolation is that David Cameron knows how desperate I was to get to support him at the launch. And Brynle will dine out for weeks on this of course.







Posted by
Glyn Davies


at
20:34

     Mark B(85) 
   Hi, I'm New   
 
 
  	Join Date
	Mar 2011
	Posts
	4

 
 
 
   
			My pregnant wife is at risk of losing one, or both babies
		
   
					All,
 

I need your help.  My wife is 15wks with twins.  Yesterday, one of the twins sack ruptured.  The other twin's sack is fine at the moment.  Both babies had a heartbeat.   I have read many websites to try to get educated as much as possible.  However, I am in search of information that can only come from experience with this nightmare.
 

How can I help my wife?  She is on bed rest and I am taking care of our 18month old girl and of her. Day to day activities are not issues.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             My concern is helping her with the possibility of losing one or both babies.  She is going to be shattered as being a mother is part of her DNA.  
 

We are soul mates and I know her extremely well, however, a women's mind is very unique and I would appreciate any insight on how best to support her during this time.
 

Thanks

Mark
				
 
 
   
				
					Last edited by Mark B(85); 12-03-11 at 04:20.
				
				
			
   
 
 
 
      Reply With Quote    
 
 
 
	    12-03-11 09:56   #2  
        Linda H 
   Netmums Parent Supporter
Disclaimer   
 
 
  	Join Date
	Jan 2005
	Posts
	20,379

 
 
 
     
					Hello Mark,

I am sorry to read about what has happened - it must be a very worrying time for you and your wife

You are looking for advice on how to support your wife if the worst happened and she lost one of the twins - have I got that right?

Being there for your wife will help, letting her talk to you when she wants to and just generally lots of TLC. There are also helplines that you and your wife could use for additional support and comfort if your worst fears came true.

Linda
				
 
 
   
				
					Last edited by Linda H; 14-03-11 at 10:07.
				
				
			
   
 
 
 
      Reply With Quote    
 
 
 
	    12-03-11 13:09   #3  
     Fiona D(249) 
   Member   
 
 
  	Join Date
	Nov 2010
	Posts
	282

 
 
 
     
					Hi Mark

Just wanted to say I'm thinking of you and your wife. Sounds like you are already a very supportive hubby, and you just need to be there for her. I had a mmc in November and hubby was the strong one. For me, I didn't need any words, a hug helps so much. It's an awful thing for any couple to go through. It was our first pregnancy and the positive thing we've taken from it is how much we really want children. 

Take care of you as well as your wife, sending you my best wishes.

Fiona
				
 
 
  
 
 
 
      Reply With Quote    
 
 
 
	    12-03-11 16:37   #4  
     Mark B(85) 
   Hi, I'm New   
 
 
  	Join Date
	Mar 2011
	Posts
	4

 
 
 
     
					Thank you for the prompt replies.  I am accepting any and all advice.  I have done some research about a variety of procedures that may help but anticipate running into doubt from my health care provider.  
 

I live in California and have read research on Amniotic sealing and Amnioinfusion.  We have an appointment on Monday.
 

I know miracles can happen as my twin and I are living proof.  My mum was 4 months pregnant when she emmigrant from England to the states.  She was told that Craig and I would not survive due to some complications.  
 

I would be very interested in hearing from as many people as possible.  
 

Thanks again, this board is a blessing.
				
 
 
  
 
 
 
      Reply With Quote    
 
 
 
	    12-03-11 18:20   #5  
     Fiona D(249) 
   Member   
 
 
  	Join Date
	Nov 2010
	Posts
	282

 
 
 
     
					Hi Mark

Just wanted to say I'll be keeping everything crossed for your appointment on Monday.

Take care

Fiona
				
 
 
  
 
 
 
      Reply With Quote    
 
 
 
	    16-03-11 01:45   #6  
     Mark B(85) 
   Hi, I'm New   
 
 
  	Join Date
	Mar 2011
	Posts
	4

 
 
 
   
			Update
		
   
					I wanted to provide an update on our situation.  We had an Ulrasound on Monday and found two strong heartbeats  Absolutely brilliant news.  We have another appointment next Monday with a specialist.  
 

Our doctors believe that the one twin that still has a complete sac is helping to keep the twin with the ruptured sac safe by keeping the uterus open and the pregnacy to continue.
 

We are still extremely anxious about the situation but feel some relief.  I do have some questions:
 

1. What is the rate at which amniotic fluid is created?  Christine is 16 weeks.

2. What are the potential effects for the twin with reduced fluid?

3. What can we do to help increase production of amniotic fluid?
 

Thanks

Mark
				
 
 
   
				
					Last edited by Mark B(85); 16-03-11 at 01:46.
				
				
			
   
 
 
 
      Reply With Quote    
 
 
 
	    16-03-11 12:00   #7  
        Tessa H(88) 
   Parent Supporter, Health Visitor
Disclaimer   
 
 
  	Join Date
	Sep 2008
	Posts
	2,361

 
 
 
     
					Hi Mark...oh that is good news  thank you so much for coming back to let us know.
 

I can see that this must be quite an anxious time for you and your wife and given the complexities of your wife's pregnancy I wonder if it would be best to ask your medical team the answers to those questions???
 

They will have all the information available and relevant to you wife's medical history, and that of your babies, and will be best placed to offer accurate answers.
 

I'm sure you will be keeping a list of things to ask at that consultant appointment next Monday Mark, so perhaps add these to that list and please do come back and let us know how that goes if you want to.
 

Tessa
				
 
 
  
 
 

 
 
      Reply With Quote    
 
 
 
	    26-05-11 00:42   #8  
     Mark B(85) 
   Hi, I'm New   
 
 
  	Join Date
	Mar 2011
	Posts
	4

 
 
 
   
			Update
		
   
					All,
 

I would like to provide an update.  The past 3 months have been hectic.  Christine is now 26+1 and both babies are doing as well as can be   We have found out that they are both boys.
 

Baby A still has a ruptured sack and appears to be smaller that average; about 3 weeks behind gestation.  Baby B is growing typically.
 

I am absolutely amazed that we have been able to get this far.  3 months ago, it did not look like we would be here.  Christine is now been admitted in hospital for the two weeks.  We are fortunate to have a level 3 perinatal NICU in the area.  They wanted her to be admitted in case the babies needed to be delivered.
 

For those that are going through this, keep faith.  We do not know how this will turn out, but our babies now have a chance at being part of this world and for that, we are thankful.
 

Thanks for all the help and I will keep this thread updated.
				
 
 
  
 
 
 
      Reply With Quote    
 
 
 
	    26-05-11 01:48   #9  
     Claire M(1284) 
   Member   
 
 
  	Join Date
	Mar 2010
	Posts
	435

 
 
 
     
					so pleased that things are looking up  you mentioned about 'keeping faith' is that in God or just in situation? well whatever sounds like things are better than you'd thought.
 

friends of mine from our church went through an experiance about 2 yrs ago where their unborn twins were suffering from 'twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome' (google it), and there was a high percentage chance one or both would die. However (after lots prayer), they are now doing really well and are about 21mths old  !!! Miracles DO happen yay!
 

I'm no expert, but i'm sure you are not that far off the stage where the drs COULD induce birth if NECESSARY. not ideal, but babies survive outside womb earlier and earlier these days. But heres wo quite a few more weeks yet..................
 

anyway saying a little prayer for you guys as i type. keep us updated x
				
 
 
  
 
 
 
  
 

Uploaded with ImageShack.us

We will keep thinking of you and your family, sending positive vibes your way and please do keep us posted 
 

Tessa

xx

Love 2u and Christine xxx

		home

 	Buy the book
|back|
 				
 	Never Let Me Go
by Kazuo Ishiguro
Kathy is a thirty one year old woman telling the story of her strange life as it nears its end. At first there is something unaccountably odd about her voice as she describes her childhood growing up at Hailsham, which in many ways sounds like an idyllic boarding school. But with the realisation of the true purpose and scope of their lives, comes an understanding of Kathy and of the young men and women who she describes. Ishiguro captures with admirable delicacy the personality traits of people that have never had the opportunity to encounter and engage with the real world, whose development has been stunted and who have learned their behaviour from watching TV shows. 

At first the characters seem implausibly well-behaved. Even given their training and isolation, is it likely that these kids would never smoke or binge because they were forbidden? And when, let out at sixteen, would they tamely follow a prescribed future as if on tramlines? They are polite, punctual, obedient, brain-washable young men and women, that strain to do their essays and their art work, aim to please, yearn for praise, never swear and put their toys away in their little chests under their beds. Or is it that their clear purpose in life and prescribed future, like many rigorous belief systems, makes them conveniently pliable? 

Putting aside the improbability of the whole concept of the novel, Ishiguro’s book works brilliantly as an exploration of what it means to be human. Throughout history, terrible things have been done in the belief that a race or class of people are less than human and can justifiably be treated like animals. Despite being ‘farmed’, the men and women Kathy describes display very human emotions, including love and jealousy, as well as their touching and authentic need to know their own origins.

At a time when the possibilities of science seem infinite, the novel questions the extent to which societies are willing to deceive themselves and exploit others for their own ends and who, ultimately, will be responsible for arbitrating and upholding what is right. 

Ishuguro never slows the pace of his novel by using three syllables where one will do, tension builds imperceptibly to a very elegant crescendo, and he spares the reader nothing of pity or reproach. NEVER LET ME GO is a subtly sinister yet moving and thought-provoking novel. 


Paula McMaster



Published by Faber & Faber, 304pp.

						These are some of the week's big religion and ethics news stories. You can talk about the stories on this thread and suggest others.


Religion stories

Christian and transgendered?

                                                Comments Post your comment
     Sign in or register to comment. 
 
   
 
          Page 2 of 2
 
 	First 
	1 
	2 
	Last 

 
 
 
    	 Comment number 101.
  At 23:47  3rd Apr 2011, peterm2 wrote:     Hoo-Woo!! LSV!

But do you think that the context spoils it? ;-)

Oh flippers, context; that's another slpiiery little fish (not lit-really of source)

And let it through, mods, pleasers; my quayboard seems to b playin up.


  

  Complain about this comment (Comment number 101)
 
 
	 Comment number 102.
  At 00:12  4th Apr 2011, Andrew wrote:     Peter

Quayboards can't play up. Honestly, random letters is one thing but random letters and idioms, boys-a-dear. 

I'm literally going to explode. 
  

  Complain about this comment (Comment number 102)
 
 
	 Comment number 103.
  At 14:53  4th Apr 2011, PaulR wrote:     Concerning the previous exchange, while the point may on the surface be purely technical, I think it's important to grasp that a bundle of information is just as much so regardless of how an individual chooses to interpret it.  An alien interpreter viewing our discussions might think of them as completely nonsensical, but that itself doesn't mean there would be no information in them.

LSV is right in one sense - information can be seen as being about generation.  The Kolmogorov analysis of the information content of a particular string is to look at it in terms of the length of the (formal) procedure needed to create that string.  In this respect, Natman's example is poorly chosen, since "fyoreolaou" does not have the same structure as "youareafool".  In fact, on a language-independent formal procedure, it appears slightly less mathematically random than its engl-ish counterpart, in that the letter 'o' appears with a certain amount of regularity.  In addition, in a procedure that can take the syntactic representation of english words as basic, the english string is going to be much easier to generate.

On the other hand, with this analysis in mind, it seems that different notions of "formal procedure" result in different valuations of information content.  Furthermore, there is a very strong likelihood of overdetermination if we're not careful.  Pete Rollins gives a cute example of exactly this kind of thing with his "godisnowhere" (I've ignored his contextual point, which I think is that little ambiguities like that are required in giving a full account of divinity and the social impact thereof).

The basic worry in giving a contextually neutral notion of information at the human scale is that of having a set of agreed fundamental principles of semantic interpretation and generation.  If one wants to follow Chomsky in thinking that all language follows a common grammatical and mathematical structure, and then think that this structure is a mirror of the structure of the real world itself, then perhaps the notion of information content in question is clear and unambiguous - it is just whatever it is in the world that you're talking about.  So it's aspects of the creator or the grounding elements of physics, depending on the Theist/Reductivist divide.

But the Mathematical notion of information does not care one way or the other as to whether the structure it is talking about is "correct" or even "in use".  It is scale-independent.  These are properties that determine the protocol of information exchange.  Information is more abstract than that, and simply ties packets and codings together.  In particular, information does not imply compressibility.

The thought is that even "@*!" has information content as a string, albeit exactly that information content contained in "012" with a translation mapping 0->@, 1->*, 2->!.  Why do we say this?  It's so that we can identify the things that are being interpreted.  Some person X for whom this string has a basic generation principle may derive content from this string that we do not.  We could perhaps have done better in transmitting that content to them by saying something with the same meaning with fewer characters.  But that can't impact on "@*!"'s being the informative token that it is - otherwise, a thing's interpretation would simply be identical to its syntactic tokening, and that strikes me as just crazy.

Intelligence is fundamentally about being able to reflect on tricks like compression by considering the notions of process and generation involved.  I think it is entirely appropriate to look at them (particularly qua "proof" in logic and mathematics) as involved in our structural analysis of the world, and I don't think we can do good science without it.  But the core point to take away here is that intelligence is a higher order notion than information, with the latter just being what the former operates over rather than something that has an ontological dependence on the former.


Now I think I can address LSV's point.  LSV, your argument is that the information content in genetic coding cannot be interpreted relative to a coding structre that has nothing else to fall back on than physics and chemistry, because it is too mathematically random.  This is random in the sense of there being no non-trivial compression algorithm.  In other words, it has no interpretation-level identities with any other physical processes, and (you conclude) has a distinctly intelligent character, clashing with any attempt at physicalistic reduction.

But for the conclusion to go through, you need to demonstrate that the lack of identity with other processes at the interpretive level means that there is no generation algorithm in purely physial or chemical terms.  I don't think this will work.  It's one thing to say "it's not like anything else", but you assume in your reply to PK that you can jump the gap from "not typically physical" to "physically irreducible".  I can see why that jump might intuitively seem natural, in that we might want to think that everything that happens physically does so as a matter of maximum generality, and that everything that occurs once occurs again.

Yet I think an entirely reasonable response might be as follows: There are identity conditions at both levels.  There is a physical explanation at the reducing physical level, while self-identity is an acceptable condition at the reduced interpretive level because there are non-circular identity conditions at the physical.  You're only ruling out self-identity at the interpretive level because you are being skeptical about the physicalistic identity conditions - this certainly constitutes a challenge to any possibility that you as an interpreter can give a non-regressive account of the information content of genetic molecules, but not of all interpretations.

From an evolutionary perspective, a generation algorithm is an entirely plausible option - the Miller-Urey experiments show how the basic proteins form as a general principle, and all that remains is some chemical explanation for how these can be combined to form a polymer.  This explanation needn't be a guarantee that they will always do so - it just needs to posit some way in which they can in order for the information content to be deterined, even if that information content is so dense as to seem incredibly probabilistically unlikely.

In summary, I think what you've erred in your argument by depending on the information/interpretation gap being closed by a prior constraint on the domain of information, when the constraint you need only affects the domain of interpretation.
  

  Complain about this comment (Comment number 103)
 
 
	 Comment number 104.
  At 14:55  4th Apr 2011, Beecefromsuff wrote:     Afternoon all, still awaiting by intelligent and considered response to appear, in the mean time.....whatbout-yee aul hands!!
  

  Complain about this comment (Comment number 104)
 
 
	 Comment number 105.
  At 21:58  4th Apr 2011, logica_sine_vanitate wrote:     PaulR - 

Thanks for your thoughts concerning information.

The fundamental question is this: can the information content of DNA be nothing more than an emergent property of the laws of nature operating in and on matter?  The answer to that question is clearly 'no'.  The genetic code is mathematically 'random' in the sense that it is algorithmically incompressible, but it also possesses specified complexity in that only certain specific sequences code for viable functioning proteins, and the wrong sequences result in failure of protein synthesis.  Therefore the genetic code is 'semantic information' not merely 'syntactic', the latter being the case with what we, in everyday parlance, would refer to as a 'random' sequence (monkey generated information).  

The problem with non-semantic algorithmically incompressible information is that any 'useful' information that happens to appear in the sequence is 'undone' by the presence of the non-useful information.  Non-useful information is not merely redundant, it is also largely semantically destructive (this can be seen in a random sequence of letters that may contain some 'English' looking words, but whatever meaning those 'words' may have has been undermined by the lack of context and the gibberish surrounding them).  Therefore junk information has to be screened out (and by 'junk' I am not referring to non-coding DNA, which may have a biological function).  How would this be possible by a purely chemical process?  Screening involves scanning against a template of target information.  In other words, the perfect semantic key has to first exist, against which the randomly generated information has to be scanned.  This is why Dawkins' weasel programme is such a fallacy, with its 'target letters' procedure (in fact, one wonders why he even needs to generate his line of Hamlet, when it already exists in the form of his target letters!!)

So we need algorithmically incompressible semantic information.  If this is an emergent property of matter, then, based on the principle of the conservation of information, the structure of matter has to contain this information, otherwise where did it come from?  But the laws of nature operate according to algorithms - a good example being the iterations observed in the formation of a crystal.  Algorithmically incompressible information, by definition, cannot emerge by such means.

Furthermore, the sequence of the genetic code (and I am not talking here about the pairing of bases but the sequence of the genome) has to be indeterminate for it to function as a code.  But this would not be the case if the sequence was determined merely by chemical affinities between the nucleotide bases of DNA (and RNA), in the same way that the sequence of the symbols of printed language would be overwhelmingly narrow and predictable if determined by the molecular structure of paper and ink alone.  The 'randomness' (i.e. informational indeterminacy) of the letters on a printed page is entirely separate from the molecular structure of paper and ink (and, in fact, that structure is not indeterminate anyway).  An example of 'information' created purely by matter would be the shape of a droplet of ink on a piece of blotting paper.  Its shape and size would be formed by physics and chemistry alone.  But if I were to write this sentence on that piece of blotting paper, I would be introducing another influence - intelligence - which would override (to some extent) the deterministic influence of the material properties of paper and ink.  The information content of what I had written could not have been created by the informational content of the molecular structure of the paper and ink, since the algorithmic nature of the latter has a smaller information content than the former.

The laws of nature alone contain a different kind of information from that contained in the genetic code.  Therefore the information that governs life must have originated from a source other than matter, and the only conceivable source of such algorithmically incompressible semantic information is intelligence.
  

  Complain about this comment (Comment number 105)
 
 
	 Comment number 106.
  At 00:27  5th Apr 2011, grokesx wrote:     @LSV

        		 'The Eve of St Agnes', William Holman Hunt,  1847-57

                

                
                 Oil on panel, 25.2 x 35.5cm

                  

                Accession number WAG 1635

                This painting is an oil sketch for Holman Hunt's large painting of the 'Eve of St Agnes', completed in 1848, which now hangs in the Guildhall Art Gallery in London. Hunt didn't finish this version until 1857, ten years after it was begun.

                Both paintings were inspired by John Keat's poem of the same name. The poem was based upon the ancient belief that if a young woman prayed to St Agnes on the eve of her feast, then she would see in her sleep the face of the man she was destined to marry. Madeleine and Porphyro, two lovers who have been kept from each other's arms by the jealous rivalry between their two families, are the principal figures of the poem and the painting. On St Agnes Eve, Porphyro gained access to Madeleine's bedroom, pretending at first to be a vision. After revealing his true identity he persuaded her to leave her father's house and marry him.

                Hunt's painting illustrates the penultimate verse of the poem, in which the two lovers are described as escaping. The following lines from Keats's poem were included in the catalogue of the 1848 Royal Academy Exhibition when the larger version was first shown:

                'They glide, like phantoms into the wide hall;

                  Like phantoms, to the iron porch they glide;

                  Where lay the Porter, in uneasy sprawl,

                  With a huge empty flagon by his side:

                  The wakeful bloodhound rose, and shook his hide,

                  But his sagacious eye an inmate owns;

                  By one, and one, the bolts full easy slide:-

                  The chains lie silent on the footworn stones

            The key turns, and the door upon its hinges groans.'

                Nobody else is awake in the poem, rather 'In all the house was heard no human sound'. However, Hunt has increased the tension of the moment of escape by adding feasting guests of Madeleine's father to the scene. These debauched partygoers are significantly placed on the left hand side (traditionally the side associated with evil), in contrast to the goodness and piety of the couple escaping through a door on the right (traditionally the side of righteousness).

                Unlike the larger painting this smaller version uses more lurid pigment, especially in the clothing of the main characters. Hunt finished the picture after his first visit to the Holy Land, during which his colour had become markedly brighter. Further details about Holman Hunt and his travels to the Holy Land are available in our online featured artist pages.

	Marine Biologist

	Marine Biologist: Dr Iain Staniland

	A-Levels: Biology, Maths, Chemistry

	Marine biologists study organisms in the world's oceans, ranging in size and complexity from viruses to whales. They examine how these organisms interact with the environment and with each other, and measure the effects of human activities and environmental changes on marine ecosystems."



	
Download the Flash Player (or enable JavaScript) to view this video online. You can also download the 10.1 MB video (closed captions or alternative audio tracks will not be available).
Dr Staniland talks about his experiences as a marine biologist (this 10.1 MB video runs for 2 minutes and 32 seconds. Closed captions are available).

School Election Book:Layout 1  13/10/09  12:29  Page 8
Guidance notes for Teachers on running an election and
counting the votes
The following information is designed to act as a basic guide to the process of running
an election and voting.
Stage 1 - Set Budget (if needed)
Stage 2 - Appoint Elections Coordinator/Returning Officer
Stage 3 - Prepare Timetable of proceedings
Summary of main proceedings:
  Book accommodation (hall or classroom for poll and count)
  Compile Register of Voters and set a ���registration��� deadline
  Announce Election by publishing a Notice of Election - to ensure that everyone is
aware of the election and the deadlines
  Set a deadline for receipt of Candidates Nomination Forms and ensure everyone
is aware of the deadline
  Adjudication of Nomination Forms
  Set a deadline for withdrawal of candidates
  Provide confirmation to candidates that nomination is valid
  Provide details to all Voters (using a Poll Card if needed)
  Make an allowance for candidates to undertake an election campaign
  Print ballot papers
  Publish a Notice of Poll - listing the candidates
  Set a date for Polling Day
  Set a date for Counting the Ballot Papers
  Declare and publish the result
Stage 4 - Register of Voters
  Application to register (refer to sample document)
  Validation of application (if necessary)
  Compilation of Register of Voters
You may already have a register of sorts already set up that can be adapted.School Election Book:Layout 1  13/10/09  12:29  Page 9
Stage 5 - Publication of Notice of Election
Publication of Notice of Election (refer to sample document), advising voters of:
  Date of Election
  Hours of Poll
  Nomination deadline
Stage 6 - Nomination of Candidates
Nomination of Candidates, consider
  Submission of Nomination Forms (refer to sample document)
  Deadline for receipt of Nomination Forms
  Setting a period for candidate withdrawals
  Checking nomination form and declaring valid
  Term of Office
  Allowing candidates to produce an election statement and conduct a campaign
Stage 7 - Information to Voters - Poll cards
Prepare poll cards advising voters when and where to vote etc (refer to sample
document)
Stage 8 - The election campaign
Make an allowance for candidates to conduct a campaign, using posters and other
material
Set pupils a project designing campaign materials, such as leaflets, posters and
rosettes
Stage 9 - Publish Notice of Poll (refer to sample document)
Publish Notice of Poll, providing a list of validly nominated candidates
Stage 10 - Prepare ballot papers for printing (refer to sample
document)
Number ballot papers sequentiallySchool Election Book:Layout 1  13/10/09  12:29  Page 10
Stage 11 - The Poll
  Establish voting procedure
  Recruit team to issue the ballot papers
  Obtain a ballot box (lock/seal it)
  Consider any signposting required
  Consider secrecy of the ballot (private voting areas)
  Record number of ballot papers issued
Stage 12 - The Counting of ballot papers
  Establish the Counting procedure
  Recruit team to count the votes
  Count number of ballot papers in the box, which should agree with the number
issued
  Sort the ballot papers into piles for each candidate according to where the voter
has made a cross or similar mark. Any spoilt ballot papers place in a separate pile.
  Total up the number for each candidate and record on the result form. The total
including any that are spoilt should agree with the total votes cast.
  The candidate with the most votes is the winner
  Declare and publish the Result (refer to sample document)

Beth sydd mor arbennig am ddolydd?

					
					
					
Beth sydd mor arbennig am ddolydd........?
Wel, dewch draw i Gyfarfod Cyffredinol Blynyddol Grŵp Dolydd Sir
Fynwy i ddod o hyd i’r ateb. Bydd yn cael ei gynnal Ddydd Gwener 8
Ebrill, 7.30pm, yn Neuadd Goffa Brynbuga.

					
					
					
					
					
					
					
					

LlunⓗJulian Woodman

Ddydd Gwener 8 Ebrill, 7.30pm

Neuadd Goffa Brynbuga

Yno, bydd Julian Woodman o’r Cyngor Cefn Gwlad, sy’n gweithio
fel Swyddog Cadwraeth Cynllunio a Monitro, yn sôn am y pethau sydd,
yn ei dyb ef, yn gwneud glaswelltiroedd blodeuog Cymru mor
arbennig.

Meddai Julian Woodman: “Yn ystod y ganrif ddiwethaf, rydyn ni
wedi colli 90% o laswelltiroedd blodeuog Cymru. Rŵan, mae’n
bwysicach nag erioed i ni gefnogi’r gwaith y mae grwpiau lleol fel
Grŵp Dolydd Sir Fynwy yn ei wneud er mwyn gwarchod a chyfoethogi’r
cynefinoedd yma.”

Yn ôl Stephanie Tyler o Grŵp Dolydd Sir Fynwy: “Erbyn hyn, mae
gennym ni fwy na 100 o aelodau ac oddeutu 40 o wirfoddolwyr. Mae
croeso i bawb ymuno â ni a dod draw i fwynhau bod allan yn yr awyr
iach, gwneud cyfeillion newydd a’n helpu i adfer ein dolydd
blodeuog.”

 


 LlunⓗJulian Woodman

Mae tegeirian y waun ac ysgall y ddôl ymhlith y blodau prin sy’n
addurno ein glaswelltiroedd blodeuog.

Gall pawb ddod draw i wrando ar y sgwrs. £3 yw’r tâl mynediad.
Gall y rhai sydd ddim yn aelodau gael cinio am £12 yn ychwanegol.
Dyma gyfle gwych i ddysgu mwy am ddolydd a chymryd rhan yng ngwaith
y Grŵp.

I gael mwy o wybodaeth am y digwyddiad, neu i gael
cyfarwyddiadau ar sut i gyrraedd y Neuadd, cysylltwch â Maggie Biss
01989 750740 / monmouthmeadows@aol.co.uk neu Caroline Howard 01291
689447.

Mae Grŵp Dolydd Sir Fynwy yn gwneud gwaith pwysig o ran cyflawni
targedau’r Cynllun Gweithredu Bioamrywiaeth Lleol trwy wella ac
adfer glaswelltiroedd er budd bywyd gwyllt.

Eleni, cafodd Grŵp Dolydd Sir Fynwy gymorth ariannol gan y
Cyngor Cefn Gwlad. I gael mwy o wybodaeth am y Grŵp, neu i gymryd
rhan yn ei weithgareddau, ewch i:
www.monmouthshiremeadows.co.uk.

 

Diwedd

Ymholiadau gan y wasg: Cysylltwch â Swyddogion y Wasg
Cyngor Cefn Gwlad Cymru, sef Brân Devey ar 02920 77 2403 neu
07747767443 neu Helen Evans ar 07717225589 neu 01248
387377.

Corff a Noddir gan Lywodraeth y Cynulliad yw’r Cyngor
Cefn Gwlad, ac mae’n gweithio i greu Cymru well lle mae pawb yn
trysori ein hamgylchedd naturiol ac yn ei warchod. Gellir cael mwy
o wybodaeth am ein gwaith ar www.ccgc.gov.uk.

Falklands : Hydrocarbons Daily Record (15 October 2007)
Submitted by Falkland Islands News Network (Juanita Brock) 16.10.2007  (Article Archived on 30.10.2007)

Crude prices closed at a record high today but demand could go down if this keeps up.


HYDROCARBONS DAILY RECORD (15 OCTOBER 2007)


 



By J. Brock (FINN)


 



TODAY’S TOP STORY:


 



OIL OPERATORS SEEK CO-OPERATION AND SWAP IDEAS


 



By J. Brock (FINN)


 



Now that the oil operators are back in London they will still be meeting together on a regular basis to swap ideas and to exchange relevant information.  Subjects like logistics, drilling and legal information not only were shared this week but have been and will be shared in the UK by all exploration companies operating in the Falklands.  The latest round of meetings in the Falklands helped to keep contact with a wide variety of government officials and advisors who will be meeting each company separately and collectively in the run-up to drilling in the North, East and South Falklands Basins.


 



Thanks to the high price of crude everyone now can ask for more money and the rig market, already tight, can also demand more money.  As previously reported in HDR the tight rig market means that at $85.00 per barrel the exploration rigs are being used for exploitation and not exploration.  Though the ideal situation for drilling happened in 1998 when crude prices were slightly under $10.00 per barrel, cheap rig rental and drilling costs are a pipe dream nowadays. 


 



The potential for huge oil finds is well documented around the Falklands, unlike the North Sea that does not have future potential for huge deposits of several billion barrels.  With better technology depths around the Falklands aren’t that much of a risk, either.


 



Co-operation is needed if the companies are to share resources and complete the drilling phase of exploration on a cost-effective basis.


 



 



CRUDE PRICES:  Monday, 15 October 2007


 



Light Sweet Crude traded at $$86.13 up $2.44 on the New York Mercantile Exchange.  Brent Crude was trading at $82.23 up $2.24 on London’s ICE Futures Market.


 



ANALYSIS:


 



Turkey’s shelling of Northern Iraq caused enough fear of supply disruption that crude prices closed at a record high today.  Another “fearful” story deals with a gas pipeline fire in Nigeria.  That didn’t help steady crude prices either. It won’t take long for people, already strapped for money to cut gasoline and heating fuel expenses.  People with more resources will seek alternative sources of energy while poorer people will be faced with the choice to heat their home one day, and eat another day.  Either way, demand will go down and with that, the price.


 



THE MARKETS:


 



FTSE 100: 6,644.30 down 86.21, FTSE250: 11,439.90 down 136.41, SmallCap:  3,856.30 down 27.99


 



DJI: 13,984.80 down 108.28, NASDAQ: 2,780.05 down 25.63, S&P500: 1,548.71 down 13.09


 



INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENTS:


 



Royal Dutch Shell Plc shut natural gas pumping at one of its Nigerian fields following a fire on a pipeline in the south of the country in the Utorogu-Ughelli gas condensate pipeline. Shell had to declare force majeure on deliveries to the nation's gas pipeline network.             


 



REGIONAL DEVELOPMENTS:


 



(Brazil)


 



From a press release:


 



Petrobras has announced that the Piranema field, 25 km off the coast of Sergipe, started producing oil in deep Northeastern Brazil waters. The Piranema oil, of excellent quality, at 44º API, is the lightest oil produced in deep waters in Brazil.  This type of oil is essential for lubricant production. With operations started in Piranema, Other Northeastern Brazilian states could also start exploring oil at greater depths.  The new field will initially produce 10,000 barrels of oil per day, a figure that may reach 30,000 in 2008. When it is at its full capacity, this field will boost Sergipe’s oil production by 60%. Chartered from Norwegian corporation Sevan Production AS, this platform is an FPSO-type unit (which produces, stores and offloads oil).  The new platform has unprecedented technical characteristics: the round hull, unlike the traditional floating systems, is more versatile and stable, rendering it safer for the operations. Chartered for an 11-year term, during the first phase of the project it will be anchored in the northern portion of the field, at a water depth of 1,090 meters, and will be connected to six wells.


 



RELEVANT SHARE PRICES: 


 



TLW: 625.50 down 2.00, DES:  29.50 down 0.25, FOGL:  142.00 up 0.50, RKH:  49.50 unchanged, BOR: 37.00 unchanged, PRE:  14.50 up 0.50, GBP:  10.25 up 0.25, GPK: 423.50 unchanged, BLT 1829.00 down 49.00

title: A view from Rural Wales: Lack of Respect.
text:
A view from Rural Wales: Lack of Respect.










skip to main  |
      skip to sidebar






A view from Rural Wales





Welsh politics and countryside





















          
        
Sunday, November 15, 2009


          
        




Lack of Respect.








I usually have a look at what Spin Doctor in the Wales on Sunday has to say - mainly because he or she often writes about the mood changing qualities of the water in Montgomeryshire. Today the column informs us of a story about.....

'two Welsh politicians who were barracked by war veterans when they continued to loudly hold an unrelated conversation during a remembrance procession through their constituency last week? A British Legion veteran felt forced to yell at them, telling the pair "You're walking around like you're in Asda and you just carried on talking"! When one of the politicians attempted to reply, the elderly man shouted "Shut your bl***y mouth - just for once in your life and listen to someone else, and you may just learn something." The politician was left shaking, while the colleague was left to placate the veterans..'.

Please note that blame for the awful 'split infinitive' rests entirely with Spin Doctor. Not sure why there should be such coyness about naming the individuals concerned. I was told about this incident soon after it happened (though not the actual words supposedly used) - which was during the remembrance procession in Newtown, in Montgomeryshire. I'm told there were 300 people on the street at the time. I'd accepted an invitation to join the procession in Welshpool, or I might have witnessed the incident myself. I'd concluded that the story damaged the dignity of Remembrance Sunday, and had not repeated it to anyone - so I must admit to being a tad surprised to see it appearing in the WoS. I'm not going to allow any names to appear in comments.







Posted by
Glyn Davies


at
14:52
